[[Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]] |weapons = [[AK-47]] [[assault rifle]]s,
[[hand grenade]]s }} On 20 November 2015, [[Islamism|Islamist]] militants took 170 [[hostage]]s and killed 20 of them in a [[mass shooting]] at the [[Radisson Blu]] hotel in [[Bamako]], the capital city of [[Mali]].{{cite news |title = Deadly Mali Hotel Attack: 'They Were Shooting at Anything That Moved' |publisher = CNN |first1=Jason |last1=Hanna |first2=Ed |last2=Payne |first3=Steve |last3=Almasy |date = 20 November 2015 |accessdate = 21 November 2015 |url = http://www.cnn.com/2015/11/20/africa/mali-shooting}} Includes video.{{cite news |first1=Dionne |last1=Searcey |first2=Adam |last2=Nossiternov |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/21/world/africa/mali-hotel-attack-radisson.html |title=Deadly Siege Ends After Assault on Hotel in Mali |work=International New York Times |date=20 November 2015 |accessdate = 21 November 2015}}{{cite news |first1=Tiemoko |last1=Diallo |first2=Adama |last2=Diarra |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/21/us-mali-attacks-idUSKCN0T90SK20151121#Q4jc5muKQQ7QpOdW.97 |title= Putin says seeks global anti-terrorism fight after 19 killed in Mali attack |work=Reuters |edition=U.S. |date=21 November 2015 |accessdate = 21 November 2015}} Malian commandos raided the hotel and freed the surviving hostages.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-34879955# |title=Mali Hotel Attack: 'No More Hostages' after Special Forces Raid |work=BBC News |date=20 November 2015 |accessdate=21 November 2015}}{{cite web |url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-34877069 |title = Mali Attack: Special Forces Storm Hotel to Free Hostages |date = 20 November 2015 |work= BBC News |accessdate = 21 November 2015}} [[Al-Mourabitoun (militant group)|Al-Mourabitoun]] claimed that it carried out the attack "in cooperation with" [[Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]]; an [[Al Qaeda]] member confirmed that the two groups cooperated in the attack.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/22/world/africa/mali-hotel-attackers-are-tied-to-an-algerian-qaeda-leader.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=first-column-region®ion=top-news&WT.nav=top-news&_r=0 |title=Mali Hotel Attackers Are Tied to an Algerian Qaeda Leader |first1=Rukmini |last1=Callimachi |first2=Naih |last2=Bulos |newspaper=International New York Times |date=21 November 2015 |accessdate=21 November 2015}} == Background == Following the [[Libyan civil war]], many ethnic [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] who had fought for the [[Gaddafi]] government and the rebels took their weapons and left for [[Azawad]] (a region in Northern Mali that the [[National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad]] (MNLA) wants to be an independent state). Following several previously failed [[Tuareg rebellion (disambiguation)|Tuareg rebellion]]s, the MNLA managed to take over the area and [[Azawadi declaration of independence|declare independence]]. However, the secular movement was soon overrun by [[Islamist]]-oriented groups such as [[MOJWA]] and [[Ansar Dine]]. The French launched [[Operation Serval|a military operation]] that ousted the rebels,{{cite web |url=https://www.rt.com/usa/322948-us-africom-mali-terrorism/ |title=Behind the scenes: US involved in Mali since 9/11 |publisher=RT}} with additional [[African-led International Support Mission to Mali|military support from the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS)]]. However, [[Northern Mali conflict|simmering tensions]] and irregular incidents continued to occur. The [[Macina Liberation Front]] is a new jihadist group operating in central and southern Mali led by the radical Muslim cleric [[Amadou Kouffa]], a strong proponent of strict Islamic law in Mali. The group draws most of its support from the [[Fulani people|Fulani]] ethnic group, who are found across the [[Sahel region]]. Kouffa is a close ally of Ansar Dine leader [[Iyad ag Ghali]]. A Human Rights Watch report said the Macina Liberation Front militants had carried out serious abuses in parts of central Mali since January and killed at least five people they accused of being aligned to the government. The group has attacked police and military particularly in the Mopti region, most recently killing three soldiers in Tenenkou in August. The Malian military recently arrested Alaye Bocari, a man they say was a key MLF financier and Kouffa's right-hand man.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-34897745|title=Mali hotel attack: Police seek info on hotel attack gunmen|work=BBC News|accessdate=24 November 2015}} The [[Radisson Blu]] hotel in [[Bamako]] is in a business district that is close to the embassies, and is frequented by foreign businesspeople and government employees.{{cite web |title=Why the Radisson Hotel in Mali was a prime target |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/mali/12007918/Why-the-Radisson-Hotel-in-Mali-was-a-prime-target.html |website=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=20 November 2015 |date=20 November 2015 |last=Blair |first=David}} It is part of a chain of up-market hotels that is operated by the [[Carlson Rezidor Hotel Group]], which has headquarters in the United States and Belgium.{{cite web |title=Where is Bamako and why has the Radisson hotel been targeted by terrorists? |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/mali-hotel-siege-bamako-radisson-6866044 |website=Daily Mirror |publisher=Trinity Mirror plc |accessdate=20 November 2015 |date=20 November 2015 |last=Dubuis |first=Anna}} == Attack == {{Campaignbox Northern Mali conflict (2012–present)}} Two gunmen arrived at the hotelCarlotta Gall, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/24/world/africa/mali-says-2-gunmen-carried-out-hotel-attack-in-bamako.html Mali Says 2 Gunmen Carried Out Hotel Attack in Bamako], ''New York Times'' (November 23, 2015). between 7 and 7:30 a.m.; according to a hotel employee, the men were driving a vehicle with diplomatic license plates. Malian army commander [[Modibo Nama Traoré]] said that at least 10 gunmen had stormed the hotel shouting "[[Allahu Akbar]]" before firing on guards and taking hostages.{{cite news |last1=Kaplan |first1=Sarah |last2=Murphy |first2=Brian |title=Gunmen attack luxury hotel in Mali capital, take 170 hostages |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/11/20/reports-gunmen-attack-luxury-hotel-in-mali-capital-take-hostages/?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-high_mm-mali-410am%3Ahomepage%2Fstory |accessdate=20 November 2015 |work=The Washington Post |date=20 November 2015}} Guinean singer [[Sekouba Bambino]], who was in the hotel but escaped, reported that the perpetrators were speaking in English.{{cite web |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/world/At-Least-27-Dead-in-Mali-Hotel-Attack-Claimed-by-Al-Qaeda-Affiliate/2015/11/21/article3139540.ece |title=At Least 27 Dead in Mali Hotel Attack Claimed by Al-Qaeda Affiliate |work=The New Indian Express}} This was supported by many other witnesses, who said the attackers spoke something that was neither [[Arabic]] nor local.{{cite news|title=The Radisson Blu siege|url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21679212-after-hotel-massacre-some-encouraging-signs-murder-mali|accessdate=29 November 2015|work=[[The Economist]]|date=28 November 2015}} Kassim Traoré, a Malian journalist, said that hostages were asked to recite the ''[[shahada]]'' in order to get released. Soon after, [[Malian special forces]] stormed the hotel.{{cite web |title=Mali attack: Special forces storm hotel to free hostages |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-34877069 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=20 November 2015 |date=20 November 2015}} According to the hotel operators, 125 guests and 13 employees were inside the hotel when the siege began. According to General Didier Dacko of the Malian Army, "about 100 hostages" were taken at the beginning of the siege. The [[Associated Press]]{{cite news |title=The Latest: UN officials say 2 attackers dead in Mali attack |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/4debb9d37ce1415994f0c96b2f05a323/latest-air-france-cancels-flight-after-attack-mali |accessdate=20 November 2015 |location=BAMAKO, Mali |work=Associated Press}} and [[Al Jazeera]] have reported that in the chaos of the initial attack, many present were able to escape, but around 170 people were held hostage.{{cite news |title='No more hostages' as Mali hotel stormed |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/11/gunmen-hostages-mali-hotel-reports-151120084719883.html |accessdate=20 November 2015 |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=20 November 2015}} A delegation of the [[Organisation internationale de la Francophonie]] was in the hotel at the time of the attack. Ten [[Chinese people|Chinese]] citizens; twenty Indian citizens;{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Islamist-gunmen-attack-luxury-hotel-in-Mali-capital/liveblog/49859711.cms |title=Live Blog: Islamist gunmen attack luxury hotel in Mali capital |work=The Times of India |date=20 November 2015 |accessdate=20 November 2015}} about a dozen American citizens, including personnel from the US Embassy;{{Citation |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EUQYmBwxX00 |accessdate=20 November 2015 |title=2015 Bamako hotel attack}} seven [[Algerian people|Algerian]] citizens, including six diplomats; two [[Russian people|Russian]] citizens; two [[Moroccan people|Moroccan]] citizens; seven [[Turkish Airlines]] staff; and an unknown number of French citizens were reported to have been among those taken hostage.Two Canadian mining executives were some of the last hostages rescued. {{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/world-africa-34815762 |title=Africa Live: Shooting at hotel in Mali's capital |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=20 November 2015}} Twelve crew from [[Air France]], who were also in the hotel, were extracted and safely released. Three United Nations staff were safely removed from the hotel, but it remains unknown how many were caught inside. Several delegates from [[United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali|MINUSMA]] were present at the hotel attending a meeting on the peace process in the country.{{cite news |title=Gunmen take hostages at Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/11/20/africa/mali-shooting/index.html |publisher=CNN |accessdate=20 November 2015}} More than 100 hostages were freed.{{cite web |title=Mali hotel attack leaves at least 27 dead after 170 taken hostage |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-11-20/mali-hotel-attack-leaves-dozens-dead/6960442 |website=ABC News |accessdate=20 November 2015 }} [[UN peacekeepers]] supported the [[Malian Armed Forces]] by reinforcing security around the hotel. 25 U.S. Special Forces were in Bamako at the time of the attack and assisted Malian forces in evacuating civilians to secure locations. An official from the [[U.S. Defense Department]] said that 22 military and civilian department personnel were in the city, including five people who were at the hotel. However, he added that everyone was accounted for and there were no reports of injuries. One member, who was outside, entered the hotel to help [[first responder]]s move civilians to secure locations while the Malian operation was ongoing. Another member helped at the Joint Operations Center, which was set up to respond to the incident. The official also said that the forces did not directly participate in the operation. A further 12 U.S. citizens were rescued by security forces, according to [[United States Africa Command|AFRICOM]].{{cite news|title=A dozen US citizens rescued after Mali hotel attack|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-3327189/US-special-forces-assist-Mali-hotel-hostage-recovery-Pentagon.html|work=dailymail.co.uk|date=21 November 2015}} Although there were earlier reports of more gunmen involved in the hotel attack, the investigation determined that in fact there were only two attackers. Bamako hotel siege - regional assembly], Reuters (November 20, 2015).{{cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/update/2015-11-20/belgian-diplomat-among-bali-victims/|title=Belgian diplomat among Mali victims|date=20 November 2015|work=ITV|accessdate=1 December 2015}} * Three Chinese executives from the [[China Railway Construction Corporation]]. * Six Russians, all employees of the [[Volga-Dnepr Airlines]] cargo company (a navigator, a flight radio operator, a [[flight engineer]], a load master, and two aircraft mechanics). * Anita Ashok Datar, an American of [[Takoma Park, Maryland]], who was a senior manager at the Palladium Group (an [[international development consulting]] firm), a former [[Peace Corps]] volunteer, and expert in global [[public health]] who was an expert in [[family planning]], reproductive health and HIV in Africa and Asia.Liam Stack, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/21/world/africa/us-victimof-mali-attack-worked-on-womens-health.html U.S. Victim of Mali Attack [http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/american-killed-mali-hotel-attack-dedicated-self-others-family-n467441 American Killed in Mali Hotel Attack Dedicated Self to Others: Family], NBC News (November 21, 2015). * Shmuel Benalal, an Israeli who was an education consultant and president of Telos Group Ltd.{{cite news |last1=Lis |first1=Jonathan |title=Israeli Among 19 Killed During Islamist Hotel Siege in Mali |url=http://www.haaretz.com/world-news/1.687474 |accessdate=21 November 2015 |agency=HaAretz |date=21 November 2015}} == Responsibility == While the attack was under way, [[Al-Mourabitoun (militant group)|Al-Mourabitoun]] claimed responsibility for it via [[Twitter]], although its claim has not been verified.{{cite web|author=Natalie Ilsley|url=http://www.newsweek.com/islamist-group-claims-responsibility-mali-attack-396659|title=Al-Mourabitoun Group Claims Responsibility for Mali Attack|work=Newsweek|date=20 November 2015}} In an audio recording provided to Al Jazeera, the group also claimed responsibility and said that it had undertaken the attack jointly with [[al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]] (AQIM).{{cite news|author=Mona Boshnaq|url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/mali-hotel-attack-latest-updates/al-mourabitoun-takes-responsibility-for-siege-al-jazeera-reports/|title=Al Mourabitoun Claims Responsibility for Mali Siege, Al Jazeera|work=The New York Times|date=20 November 2015}} Al-Mourabitoun is made up of [[Tuaregs]] and [[Arabs]] from northern Mali and is affiliated with AQIM. The group, led by [[Mokhtar Belmokhtar]], formed in 2013 and is based in the [[Sahara Desert]].{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/20/us-mali-hotel-claim-idUSKCN0T91YM20151120|title=Al Qaeda-affiliated group claims Mali hotel attack|agency=Reuters|date=20 November 2015}} The [[Macina Liberation Front]] also claimed responsibility for the attack. == Reactions == [[President of Mali|Malian President]] [[Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta]] cut short his visit to [[Chad]] in order to return to Bamako and coordinate the response. Mali also declared a 10-day state of emergency.{{cite web|url=http://post.jagran.com/Mali-declares-10day-state-of-emergency-following-hotel-attack-1448080713|title=Mali declares 10-day state of emergency following hotel attack|date=21 November 2015|publisher=jagran.com}} In a press conference, French Foreign Minister [[Laurent Fabius]] stated that France will take "all steps necessary" to fight the attackers in Bamako. A crisis unit was set up in the [[Embassy of France in Bamako|embassy]]. Forty officers from the [[National Gendarmerie]]'s [[National Gendarmerie Intervention Group|GIGN]] [[special forces]] unit, along with ten forensic and criminal officers, were sent to "advise and support" Malian security forces.{{cite news|title = World News liveblog|url = http://live.reuters.com/Event/World_News?ShowComments=0|agency = Reuters|accessdate = 20 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2015/nov/20/mali-hotel-attack-gunmen-take-hostages-in-bamako-live-updates|title=Mali hotel attack: gunmen take hostages in Bamako – live updates|date=20 November 2015|work=The Guardian|accessdate=20 November 2015}} [[Air France]] flights to and from Bamako were suspended for the day. The [[United Nations Security Council]]{{cite news|title = The Latest: Security Council Strongly Condemns Mali Attack|url = https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/11/20/world/africa/ap-af-mali-attack-the-latest.html|website = The New York Times|accessdate = 20 November 2015}} condemned the attack.{{cite web|title = China strongly condemns Mali hotel attack, confirms 3 nationals killed |url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2015-11/21/c_134839619.htm|website = Xinhua News Agency|accessdate = 20 November 2015}} Australia advised its citizens not to travel to Mali and advised those in country to leave.{{cite web|title=Travel Advice for Mali |url=http://smartraveller.gov.au/countries/mali |website=smartraveller.gov.au |accessdate=20 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120205411/http://smartraveller.gov.au/countries/mali |archivedate=20 November 2015 }} Similar warnings were made by the [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office|Foreign Office]] in the [[United Kingdom]] advised British nationals to remain indoors and follow the instructions of the local government authorities.{{cite web|title = Mali travel advice|url = https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/mali|website = gov.uk|accessdate = 20 November 2015}} The United States condemned the attack{{cite web|title = Statement from NSC Spokesman Ned Price on the Terrorist Attack in Mali|url = https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2015/11/20/statement-nsc-spokesman-ned-price-terrorist-attack-mali|website = The White House|accessdate = 20 November 2015}} and confirmed continuing coordination of its officials in the country to verify the location of all citizens in Mali and that it was "prepared to assist the Malian government in the coming days as it investigates this tragic terrorist attack."{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.com/Detail/2015/11/20/438490/US-White-House-Mali-attak-Bamako-|title=US ready to help Mali govt.: White House |publisher=presstv.com}} The embassy urged its citizens to [[shelter in place]], follow government instructions and contact their family.{{cite web|title = Messages for U.S. Citizens {{!}} Bamako, Mali – Embassy of the United States|url = http://mali.usembassy.gov/sm_11202015.html|website = mali.usembassy.gov|accessdate = 20 November 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151120213122/http://mali.usembassy.gov/sm_11202015.html|archive-date = 20 November 2015|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}} The Russian city of [[Ulyanovsk Oblast]], home of five of the victims, declared 23 November a mourning day.[http://rbth.com/news/2015/11/22/bodies-of-rusian-hostages-killed-in-mali-to-be-transported-home-in-a-week_542967 Russia Beyond the Headlines: Bodies of Russian hostages killed in Mali to be transported home in a week] Malian President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita later declared three days of national mourning in Mali. Ahead of the three days of national mourning, the chairman of the West African regional bloc Ecowas, Senegal's President [[Macky Sall]], visited Bamako to show support. He said on Sunday: "Mali will never be alone in this fight, we are all committed because we are all involved." [[Senegal]], [[Mauritania]] and [[Guinea]] are also observing the mourning. ==Investigation== Three days after the attack, the Malian government released photographs of the corpses of the two attackers. The men were clean-shaven and appeared to be in their 20s. One "had visible bullet wounds to his upper body." The authorities have not been able to identify the men and urged members of the public with information to come forward. Al Mourabitoun, which claimed responsibility for the attack, said that the men were Abdul Hakim al-Ansari and Mu'adh al-Ansari, but this claim has not been verified. On November 22, 2015, two separate police sources speaking to [[Agence-France Presse]] on condition of [[Anonymous source|anonymity]] said that "two foreigners" along with "three or four accomplice" were responsible for the attack.[http://www.dw.com/en/investigation-into-mali-attack-points-to-two-foreigners/a-18868048 Investigation into Mali attack points to 'two foreigners'], [[Deutsche Welle]] (November 22, 2015). On November 27, 2015, Malian special forces arrested two Malian men in their early 30s on the outskirts if Bamako in connection with the attack.Faith Karimi & Brent Swails, [http://www.cnn.com/2015/11/27/africa/mali-hotel-attack-arrest/ Mali arrests 2 suspects in hotel terror attack], CNN (November 27, 2015). The men were linked to the attack by a mobile phone found at the scene of the attack. == See also == {{Portal|2010s|Mali|Terrorism}} * [[2003 Marriott Hotel bombing]] * [[Islamabad Marriott Hotel bombing|2008 Islamabad Marriott Hotel bombing]] * [[2008 Mumbai attacks]] * [[2012 Malian coup d'état]] * [[2015 Corinthia Hotel attack]] * [[2016 Bamako attack]] == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bamako attacks}} [[Category:Attacks on hotels]] [[Category:Diplomatic incidents]] [[Category:History of Bamako]] [[Category:Hostage taking]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism in Mali]] [[Category:Islamic terrorist incidents in the 2010s]] [[Category:Mass murder in 2015]] [[Category:Mass shootings]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents attributed to al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]] [[Category:Organisation internationale de la Francophonie]] [[Category:Radisson Hotels]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in Mali in 2015]] [[Category:November 2015 events]] [[Category:Attacks on tourists]]

[[File:48HFP.jpg|thumb|285x285px|Logo for the 48 Hour Film Project, as of 2018]] The '''48 Hour Film Project''' is an annual [[film]] competition in which teams of filmmakers are assigned a [[genre]], a [[Character (arts)|character]], a [[Theatrical property|prop]], and a [[Dialogue|line of dialogue]], and have 48 hours to create a [[short film]] containing those elements. The competition has been active since 2001. In the weeks after the 48 hours of filmmaking are complete, screenings are held in each city and a winner is chosen to represent that city at [[Filmapalooza]]—a festival that features "best of" screenings of the winners from each city. Filmapalooza is hosted by a different city each year.{{cite web |url=http://www.48hourfilm.com/about/history.php |publisher=48 Hour Film Project |title=The 48 Hour Film Project: What We're About |date=April 2010 |accessdate=2010-04-04 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325133858/http://www.48hourfilm.com/about/history.php |archivedate=25 March 2010 |deadurl=no}} The most recent Filmapalooza was held in [[Paris|Paris, France]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.48hourfilm.com/filmapalooza/2018|title=Filmapalooza 2018 @ 48 Hour Film Project|website=www.48hourfilm.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-17}} == Background == The competition began in [[Washington, D.C.]], in 2001. It was created by Mark Ruppert and is produced by Ruppert and Liz Langston. In 2009, nearly 40,000 filmmakers made around 3,000 films in 76 cities across the globe. After the 48 hours of filmmaking are complete, each city screens all the competing films, and a jury subsequently vote on the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd best films. Most cities also give out awards to their films in several categories, including directing, writing, and acting; an Audience Choice award is sometimes voted on as well, by the audience of the screenings in each city. The film that wins 1st place goes on to represent their city at [[Filmapalooza]]—a festival that features "best of" screenings of the winners from each city. Filmapalooza is hosted by a different city each year. The most recent Filmapalooza was held in [[Paris|Paris, France]]. ==Related competitions== In 2003, the creators of the 48 Hour Film Project created the National Film Challenge, which is an annual three-day film competition with roughly the same structure as the 48 Hour Film Project, except that the films are mailed in when completed and then screened on-line, rather than being shown in movie theater in the local city.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmchallenge.org|title=National Film Challenge|date=April 2010|publisher=National Film Challenge|accessdate=2009-04-04}} In 2008, this competition was opened to filmmakers from around the world and although the name was not officially changed, the runner-up hailed from Utrecht, Netherlands. The organizers of the [[Auckland]] competition split off from the 48 Hour Film Project after the 2003 competition and formed [[48HOURS]], which is now a wholly separate organization that runs a similar competition in [[New Zealand]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.48hours.co.nz/about/|title=About HP48Hours {{!}} 48HOURS 2018|website=www.48hours.co.nz|language=en|access-date=2018-08-17}} In 2006, the producers of the National Film Challenge began the International Documentary Challenge (also known as the "Doc Challenge") in which participating filmmakers produce a documentary in under five days.{{cite web|url=http://www.docchallenge.org/|title=Doc Challenge|date=April 2010|publisher=Doc Challenge|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100402070547/http://www.docchallenge.org/|archivedate=2 April 2010|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2010-04-04}} In 2011, 48 Go Green split off from 48 Hour Film Project to become a separate, independent organization. 48 Go Green had a similar style of competition. The primary differences were an ecological theme, and an entirely online competition to allow worldwide participation. 48 Go Green and 48 Hour Film Project parted ways following a disagreement between 48 Hour Film Project and co-producers Francesco Vitali and Christos Siametis.{{cite web|url=http://www.48gogreendisclaimer.com/|title=48 Go Green Disclaimer|accessdate=19 July 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.48gogreen.com/page/1|title=48 Go Green: The Creation|publisher=Creamyw Ltd|accessdate=19 July 2012}} 48 Go Green soon became [[48FILM Project]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiegored.com/noticias/49385/The-48-Film-Project-Officially-Announced/|title=The 48 Film Project Officially Announced|author=Jorge Guevara|date=20 February 2014|publisher=San Altıntaş]] |assailants=<!-- or | assailant = --> |susperps=<!-- or | susperp = --> |weapons=Canik55 TP9 Compact 9mm [[pistol]]<ref>{{cite web|title=What Gun Was Used to Assassinate the Russia’s Ambassador to Turkey?|url=http://www.thefirearmblog.com/blog/2016/12/20/gun-used-assassinate-russian-ambassador-turkey/|website=thefirearmblog.com|accessdate=21 December 2016}}</ref> |numparts=<!-- or |litigation= |website=<!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> |module= }} {{Campaignbox Spillover of the Syrian Civil War}} [[Andrei Karlov]], the [[List of ambassadors of Russia to Turkey|Russian Ambassador to Turkey]], was assassinated by Mevlüt Mert Altıntaş, an off-duty Turkish police officer,<ref name="telegraph"/> at an art exhibition in [[Ankara]], [[Turkey]] on the evening of 19 December 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mevlut Mert Altintas: The policeman accused of killing Russian ambassador Andrey Karlov?|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/12/19/turkish-police-officer-shot-dead-russian-ambassador-andrey-karlov/|accessdate=20 December 2016|work=The Telegraph}}</ref><ref name=221a>{{cite news|title=Turkish police detain six after Russian ambassador shot dead|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-russia-diplomat-idUSKBN1490MK|accessdate=20 December 2016|work=Reuters|date=20 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-38369962|title=Russian ambassador to Turkey Andrei Karlov shot dead in Ankara|date=19 December 2016|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=20 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first1=Shaun|last1=Walker|first2=Kareem|last2=Shaheen|first3=Martin|last3=Chulov |title=Russian ambassador to Turkey killed in Ankara shooting |date=19 December 2016 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/19/russian-ambassador-to-turkey-wounded-in-ankara-shooting-attack}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-russia-diplomacy-idUSKBN1481RE|title=Russian ambassador shot dead in Ankara gallery|date=19 December 2016|publisher=|via=Reuters}}</ref><ref name=Reuters>{{cite news |first1=Tuvan|last1=Gumrukcu|first2=Daren|last2=Butler |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-russia-diplomacy-idUSKBN1481RE |title=Russian ambassador gunned down in Ankara, Russian agency says killed |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=19 December 2016}}</ref> The assassination took place after several days of protests in Turkey over [[Russian involvement in the Syrian Civil War]] and the [[Aleppo offensive (November–December 2016)|battle over Aleppo]].<ref name=":0" />
{{external media | float = right | width = 275px | video1 ={{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/gunfire-wounds-russian-ambassador-in-turkey-reports-say/2016/12/19/ae32d1c8-c608-11e6-85b5-76616a33048d_story.html|title=Washington Post: ''Russian ambassador to Turkey assassinated in Ankara by off-duty police officer''}} }}
== Background == The assassination took place after a long period of highly polarized and incited political atmosphere in Turkey,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2015/10/turkey-isis-russia-pkk/408988/|title=Turkey Is in Serious Trouble|author=Soner Cagaptay|date=5 October 2015|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=27 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/global-opinions/wp/2016/12/20/turkeys-permanent-state-of-crisis/|title=Turkey’s permanent state of crisis|author=Soner Cagaptay|date=20 December 2016|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=27 December 2016}}</ref> and after several days of protests by Turks against [[Russian involvement in the Syrian Civil War]] and in particular the [[Aleppo offensive (November–December 2016)|battle over Aleppo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/russia-get-out-syria-thousands-join-protest-turkey-border-1298309781|title='Russia, get out of Syria': Thousands join protest on Turkey border|date=17 December 2016|publisher=MiddleEastEye|accessdate=27 December 2016}}</ref> Russian and Turkish officials held talks on brokering a ceasefire in Syria during the [[Aleppo offensive (November–December 2016)#Ceasefires and evacuation|evacuation of Aleppo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/turkey-russia-meet-wednesday-syrias-aleppo-turkish-official-091517656.html|title=Turkey talking to Russia on ceasefire, evacuation from Syria's Aleppo|publisher=}}</ref> Russia, Turkey and Iran planned to meet to negotiate a settlement over the [[Syrian Civil War]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-turkey-russia-idUSKBN1480ZO|title=Russia, Iran and Turkey to hold Syria talks in Moscow on Tuesday|date=19 December 2016|publisher=|via=Reuters}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/syria-talks-between-iran-turkey-and-russia-will-still-go-on-in-moscow-despite-ambassadors-assassination-2016-12|title=Syria talks between Iran, Turkey, and Russia will still go on in Moscow despite ambassador's assassination|publisher=}}</ref>
== Assassination == Karlov, the Russian Ambassador to Turkey, had been invited to deliver a speech at the opening of an exhibition of Turkish photography of the Russian countryside. The exhibition, "Russia through Turks' eyes", was being held at the Cagdas Sanat Merkezi centre for modern arts in [[Ankara]]'s [[Çankaya, Ankara|Çankaya district]].<ref name="SoichetThompson">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/12/19/europe/turkey-russian-ambassador-shot/index.html|title=Russia's ambassador to Turkey assassinated in Ankara|website=CNN|last1=CNN|first1=Catherine E. Shoichet and Nick Thompson|accessdate=19 December 2016}}</ref>
Mevlüt Altıntaş entered the hall using police identification, leading gallery attendees to believe he was one of Karlov's personal bodyguards.<ref name="ABCNews20Dec" /> Karlov had begun his speech when Altıntaş fired several shots at the Russian ambassador from the back, fatally wounding him and injuring several other people.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/12/19/europe/turkey-russian-ambassador-shot/index.html|title=Gunman shouted 'Do not forget Aleppo!' as he shot ambassador|last=Shoichet|first=Catherine E.|last2=Thompson|first2=Nick|date=|website=CNN|publisher=|access-date=20 December 2016|last3=Grinberg|first3=Emanuella}}</ref>
After shooting Karlov, Altıntaş circled the room, smashing pictures that were on display and shouting in Arabic and Turkish: "[[Takbir|''Allahu Akbar'']] (God is the greatest). We are the descendants of those who supported the Prophet Muhammad, for jihad. Do not forget Aleppo, do not forget Syria"<ref name=":0" /><ref name="Reuters" /><ref name="SoichetThompson" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/turkey/1.760063|title=Turkey: Russia's ambassador in Ankara killed in shooting attack by police officer|work=Haaretz|agency=Reuters and the Associated Press|accessdate=19 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="Independent">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/russian-ambassador-dead-turkey-death-andrey-karlov-shot-ankara-back-murder-assassination-latest-a7484991.html|title=Russian ambassador to Turkey dead: Andrey Karlov dies after being shot in Ankara|date=19 December 2016|newspaper=[[The Independent]]}}</ref> and "We die in Aleppo, you die here".<ref>{{cite news|title=Assassination in an art gallery|url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21712117-apparent-killer-was-turkish-policeman-angry-about-russian-atrocities-syria-ambassadors|accessdate=23 December 2016|work=[[The Economist]]|date=23 December 2016}}</ref> Shortly after, Altıntaş was shot and killed by Turkish security forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/la-fg-russian-ambassador-turkey-attacked-20161219-story.html|title=Off-duty police officer identified in fatal shooting of Russia's ambassador to Turkey|last2=King|first2=Laura|date=19 December 2016|website=[[Sun-Sentinel]]|access-date=19 December 2016|last1=Umar|first1=Farooq}}</ref> Karlov was taken to the hospital, but died from his injuries.<ref name=":0" />
=== Motivation === Turkish President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] declared that the shooting was designed to disrupt the warming [[Russia–Turkey relations]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/gunfire-wounds-russian-ambassador-in-turkey-reports-say/2016/12/19/ae32d1c8-c608-11e6-85b5-76616a33048d_story.html|title=Turkish police officer, invoking Aleppo, guns down Russian ambassador in Ankara|publisher=}}</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' suggested a possible motive was revenge for the [[Russian Air Force]]'s targeting of rebel-held areas in [[Aleppo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/19/world/europe/what-happened-turkey-russia-assassination-analysis.html|title=Turkey, Russia and an Assassination: The Swirling Crises, Explained|date=19 December 2016|website=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=19 December 2016|last1=Fisher|first1=Max|quote=That may hint at his motive: The Russian Air Force was a key part of the Syrian government’s successful assault on rebel-held parts of Aleppo, which included widespread attacks on civilians.}}</ref>
Although seemingly an act of revenge against Russian [[Aleppo offensive (November–December 2016)|military involvement in Aleppo]] as part of the ongoing Syrian Civil War, some have suspected [[Islamic extremism]] or [[anti-Russian sentiment]] to be the cause of the attack. President-elect of the United States [[Donald Trump]] accused the assassin of being "a radical Islamic terrorist",<ref name="Conway">{{cite news|last1=Conway|first1=Madalaine|title=Trump calls Russian ambassador's assassin a 'radical Islamic terrorist'|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/12/donald-trump-russia-assassination-232834|work=POLITICO|date=19 December 2016}}</ref> and the [[Russian State Duma]] said that "The culprits in this monstrous provocation, both the executors and those who guided the terrorist's hand by instigating Russophobia, ethnic, religious and confessional hatred, extremism and fanaticism, must face their deserved punishment".<ref>{{cite news|title=Putin moves major press conference to attend funeral of slain diplomat Karlov|url=https://www.rt.com/politics/371104-putin-reschedules-major-presser-to/|work=RT International|date=21 December 2016|language=en-EN}}</ref>
Allegations of [[North Atlantic Treaty Organization|NATO]] involvement have circulated among government officials and commentators, as well as involvement by the [[Salafist jihadism|jihadist]] movements of [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) and [[Jabhat Fatah al-Sham]] (formerly known as Al-Nusra Front/[[al-Qaeda]] in Syria)<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/12/19/who-shot-russias-ambassador-to-turkey-it-could-be-a-lot-of-people.html|title=Any number of groups could have wanted Russian ambassador dead|date=19 December 2016|work=CNBC|last1=Kemp|first1=Ted}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2016/12/19/russian-ambassador-to-turkey-shot-in-targeted-attack/|title=Russian ambassador to Turkey killed in targeted attack|date=19 December 2016|work=New York Post|last1=Steinbuch|first1=Yaron}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/russia-ambassador-shooting-turkey-nato-security-services-andrey-karlov-a7485296.html|title=Russian MP blames Nato conspiracy for killing of ambassador in Turkey|date=19 December 2016|work=The Independent|last1=Kentish|first1=Ben}}</ref> – two groups which Turkey has been accused of supporting in the past – have been made.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/nov/18/turkey-cut-islamic-state-supply-lines-erdogan-isis|title=Turkey could cut off Islamic State’s supply lines. So why doesn't it?|date=18 November 2015|work=The Guardian|last1=David|first1=Graeber}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/Default.aspx?PageID=238&NID=107404&NewsCatID=358|title=CIA apologizes to Turkey over ISIL oil trade allegations – AMERICAS|publisher=}}</ref> Turkish authorities are reportedly investigating Aydintas' links to the [[Gülen movement]]; in a speech, [[President of Turkey|Turkish President]] Recep Tayyip Erdoğan claimed that the perpetrator was a member of "FETÖ".<ref name="ABCNews20Dec">{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-12-20/ankara-russian-ambassador-shooting-who-is-mevlut-mert-aydintas/8135510|title=Who was the Ankara assassin?|date=20 December 2016|work=ABC News|language=en-AU}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr/cumhurbaskani-erdogan-ankara-da-siyaset-2365707/|title=Erdoğan resmen açıkladı: Suikastçı FETÖ mensubu|trans-title=Erdoğan officially announces: Assassin is FETÖ member|work=Milliyet Haber|accessdate=21 December 2016}}</ref> The attack was praised by ISIL and [[al-Qaeda in Syria|al-Qaeda]] affiliated accounts on [[social media]].<ref name="Social media Heavy">{{cite news|url=http://heavy.com/news/2016/12/isis-islamic-state-tahwid-allahu-akbar-assassination-attempt-russian-ambassador-to-turkey-andrei-karlov-twitter-video-claim/|title=ISIS ‘Celebrates’ Assassination of Russian Ambassador to Turkey Andrei Karlov|date=19 December 2016|work=Heavy.com|last1=Prince|first1=S.J.}}</ref> The words spoken by the assassin are similar to the unofficial anthem of Jabhat Fatah al-Sham.<ref>"[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/12/19/turkish-police-officer-shot-dead-russian-ambassador-andrey-karlov/ Mevlut Mert Altıntaş: The policeman accused of killing Russian ambassador Andrey Karlov?]". ''The Daily Telegraph''. 20 December 2016.</ref>
== Victim == {{Main article|Andrei Karlov}} [[File:Andrey Karlov 2016.jpg|thumb|180px|Karlov in 2016]] Born in Moscow in 1954, Andrei Gennadyevich Karlov was educated at the [[Moscow State Institute of International Relations]] and the Diplomatic Academy. He began his career with the government at the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Soviet Union)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the USSR]] in 1976. Karlov went on to hold various diplomatic positions at the Russian embassy to [[North Korea]]. He had been Russian ambassador to Turkey since July 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Who was Andrey Karlov? What we know about the Russian ambassador to Turkey|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/12/19/andrey-karlov-know-russian-ambassador-turkey/|work=The Telegraph}}</ref>
Andrei Karlov is the fourth Russian diplomat to have died in the line of duty, after [[Alexander Griboyedov]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://lenta.ru/articles/2016/12/20/killed_ambassador|title=Четвертый на посту: посол России в Турции Андрей Карлов|last=|first=|date=20 December 2016|work=Lenta.ru|trans-title=Fourth in the line of duty: Russian Ambassador Andrei Karlov killed in Turkey|access-date=20 December 2016|via=}}</ref> [[Vatslav Vorovsky]] and [[Pyotr Voykov]], a Soviet envoy to Poland.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bromwich|first1=Jonah Engel|title=Who Was Andrey Karlov, the Russian Ambassador Killed in Turkey?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/19/world/europe/andrey-karlov-wiki.html|accessdate=20 December 2016|work=The New York Times|date=19 December 2016}}</ref>
== Perpetrator == {{Infobox murderer | name = Mevlüt Altıntaş | image = | image_size = | caption = | birthname = Mevlüt Mert Altıntaş | occupation = Riot policeman | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1994|06|24}} | birth_place = [[Söke]], Turkey | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2016|12|19|1994|06|24}} | death_place = [[Ankara]], Turkey | cause = Gunshot | penalty = | date = | targets = [[Andrei Karlov]] | locations = [[Ankara]] | fatalities = 1 | injuries = 3 | weapons = [[Handgun]] }}
The assassin was identified as '''Mevlüt Mert Altıntaş''' ({{IPA-tr|ˈmevlyt ˈmæɾt ˈɑɫtɯntɑʃ|lang}}; 24 June 1994 – 19 December 2016), an off-duty Turkish [[Cevik Kuvvet|riot police]] officer.<ref name="telegraph"/>
Altıntaş grew up in a [[secular]] family from the town [[Söke]] of [[Aydın Province]] in the Aegean region of western Turkey.
After being rejected from university twice,<ref name="Reuters 23 Dec">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-russia-diplomat-assailant-idUSKBN14C1FM|title=Russian envoy's killer remembered as lonely boy, not angry jihadist|last1=Gumrukcu|first1=Tuvan|date=23 December 2016|work=Reuters}}</ref> he graduated from [[İzmir]] Police School in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gaceta.es/noticias/asesino-andrei-karlov-policia-turco-22-anos-19122016-1943|title=El asesino de Andrei Karlov, un policía turco de 22 años|date=19 December 2016 |website=La Gaceta|accessdate=19 December 2016}}</ref> His sister was quoted as saying that "he started to perform prayer five times a day in police school".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/police-school-changed-assassin-of-russian-envoy-sister.aspx?pageID=238&nID=107750&NewsCatID=509|title=Police school changed assassin of Russian envoy: Sister|date=26 December 2016 |website=Hürriyet Daily News|accessdate=26 December 2016}}</ref> He served on an elite Ankara riot police unit for two and a half years, and had been part of the security detail for Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan on eight occasions since July 2016.<ref name="telegraph">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/12/21/russian-ambassadors-assassin-guarded-recep-tayyip-erdogan/|title=Russian ambassador's assassin 'guarded Recep Tayyip Erdogan'|date=21 December 2016 |website=The Telegraph|accessdate=24 December 2016}}</ref>
A Turkish newspaper reported that Altıntaş had been suspended in early October 2016 for suspected involvement in the [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt]], but returned to duty in mid-November.<ref>{{cite news|title=Karlov's assassin stayed in hotel close to scene, took 11 shots|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/karlovs-assassin-stayed-in-hotel-close-to-scene-took-11-shots.aspx?PageID=238&NID=107528&NewsCatID=509|accessdate=20 December 2016|publisher=Hürriyet Daily News|date=20 December 2016}}</ref>
Altıntaş had visited [[Qatar]] several times and what he did while in Qatar was being investigated after he killed the ambassador.<ref name="Qatar">{{cite news|title=The Killer of the Ambassador of Russia in Turkey Visited Qatar Several Times|url=http://en.alalam.ir/news/1902831|agency=Alalam|date=26 December 2016}}</ref>
Altıntaş' body was rejected by his family; his parents stated that "We are ashamed of him because of the murder and we will not claim the body of a traitor." His body was buried in a cemetery for unidentified and unclaimed corpses.<ref>{{cite news|title=Family rejects body of Russian envoy's killer|url=http://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2017/01/05/family-rejects-body-of-russian-envoys-killer|accessdate=16 January 2017|publisher=Daily Sabah Turkey|date=16 January 2017}}</ref>
== Aftermath == The day after the killing, Turkish authorities arrested a number of Altıntaş' family members in his home [[Aydın Province|province of Aydin]], as well as his flatmate in Ankara, holding the family members for one day.<ref name="221a" /><ref>[http://www.dailysabah.com/war-on-terror/2016/12/22/family-members-of-russian-envoys-assailant-released-from-custody Family members of Russian envoy's assailant released from custody – Daily Sabah], accessdate: 23 December 2016</ref> [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Russian Foreign Minister]] [[Sergey Lavrov]] also confirmed that a Russian investigative team was scheduled to arrive in Turkey on 20 December to assist with the investigation.<ref name=":1" />
== Reactions == <!--Please read the talk page discussion before adding reactions to this section--> Many governments and [[heads of state]] condemned the attack and offered condolences to the family of Karlov and other victims of the shooting, as well as to the Russian people.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mzv.cz/jnp/en/issues_and_press/mfa_statements/x2016_12_19_mfa_of_the_czech_republic_condemns_the.html|title=Statement of the MFA of the Czech Republic on the Assassination of Russian Ambassador to Turkey|date=19 December 2016|website=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Czech Republic)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Czech Republic]]|accessdate=19 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2016/12/265774.htm|title=The Assassination of Russian Ambassador to Turkey Andrey Karlov|newspaper=U.S. Department of State|access-date=20 December 2016}}</ref>
While ISIL has not claimed responsibility for the assassination, it has been celebrated by its supporters.<ref>"[http://heavy.com/news/2016/12/isis-islamic-state-tahwid-allahu-akbar-assassination-attempt-russian-ambassador-to-turkey-andrei-karlov-twitter-video-claim/ ISIS ‘Celebrates’ Assassination of Russian Ambassador to Turkey Andrei Karlov]". [[Heavy.com]]. 19 December 2016.</ref> The Islamist [[Army of Conquest|Jaish al-Fatah]] coalition, which includes the [[Jabhat Fatah al-Sham]] (formerly Al-Nusra Front), claimed responsibility for the assassination, according to the [[Egypt]]ian newspaper ''[[List of newspapers in Egypt|Al-Youm Al-Sabea]]''.<ref>"[http://tass.com/world/921186 Media: Jaish al-Fatah claims responsibility for murder of Russian ambassador]". [[Russian News Agency TASS]]. 21 December 2016.</ref>
A [[Qatar]]i journalist, Elham Badar, said the shooting was a 'human' response to 'Russian barbarism' in Aleppo and elsewhere in the conflict.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/qatari-journalist-russian-ambassador-shooting-dead-deserved-syria-crimes-air-strikes-andrei-karlov-a7486321.html|title=Qatari journalist posts: Russia ‘deserved’ ambassador killing for its ‘crimes’ in Syria|work=The Independent|accessdate=21 December 2016}}</ref> ''[[New York Daily News]]'' columnist [[Gersh Kuntzman]] attracted criticism when he compared Karlov's murder to the assassination of Nazi German diplomat [[Ernst vom Rath]] by Jewish student [[Herschel Grynszpan]], saying "justice has been served."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gersh|first1=Kuntzman|title=Assassination of Russian Ambassador Andrei Karlov was not terrorism, but retribution for Vladimir Putin’s war crimes|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/don-cry-russia-slain-envoy-putin-lackey-article-1.2917281|website=New York Daily News|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Pfeiffer|first1=Alex|title=NY Daily News Columnist Defends Assassination Of Russian Ambassador|url=http://dailycaller.com/2016/12/20/ny-daily-news-columnist-defends-assassination-of-russian-ambassador/|accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref> The Russian [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] later demanded an apology from the ''New York Daily News'' following the article's publication.<ref>{{cite web|title=Russian Foreign Ministry demands apology from NY Daily News – spokesperson|url=https://www.rt.com/news/371187-russia-us-daily-apology/|publisher=RT|accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref> Ukrainian MP [[Volodymyr Parasiuk]], famous for his [[Euromaidan]] speech, has called the Russian ambassador's assassin a "hero".<ref>"[https://www.rt.com/news/371006-unkraine-reaction-russian-ambassador/ Ukrainian MP calls Russian ambassador’s killer ‘a hero,’ FB reacts with outrage]". ''RT.'' 20 December 2016.</ref>
A woman in the board of [[Al Jazeera]] said that she believes the murder of Andrey Karlov was justified because of the bloodshed the country has contributed to in the [[Syrian civil war]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/al-jazeera-board-member-says-russia-deserved-ambassador-killing-for-its-crimes-in-syria-35308882.html|title=Al Jazeera board member says Russia ‘deserved’ ambassador killing for its ‘crimes’ in Syria|work=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
=== Turkish reaction === In Turkey, President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] said in a video message that "Turkey-Russia relations are vital for the region and those who aimed to harm ties were not going to achieve their goals", after having spoken to Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]], adding that they "both agreed the assassination of Russia's ambassador to Ankara by a gunman was an act of provocation by those looking to harm relations of our countries."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pamuk|first1=Humeyra|last2=Toksabay|first2=Ece|last3=Dolan|first3=David|title=Turkey's Erdogan says Putin agrees shooting of ambassador was provocation|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-russia-diplomat-idUSKBN14829U|website=Reuters|accessdate=19 December 2016|date=19 December 2016}}</ref> The Turkish [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Turkey)|Foreign Ministry]] pledged to spare no effort to not let "this attack cast a shadow on the Turkish-Russian friendship."<ref>{{cite news|title=Turkish MFA says won't allow killing of ambassador 'cast shadow' over Turkish-Russian friendship|url=http://www.dailysabah.com/diplomacy/2016/12/19/turkish-mfa-says-wont-allow-killing-of-ambassador-cast-shadow-over-turkish-russian-friendship|work=DailySabah}}</ref> [[List of Ministers of Foreign Affairs (Turkey)|Turkish Foreign Minister]] [[Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu]] announced that the street in which the Russian embassy is located would be named after the ambassador.<ref name="221a" />
=== Russian reaction === [[File:Putin, Lavrov, Bortnikov, Naryshkin (2016-12-19).jpg|thumb|right|250px|Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] discussing countermeasures after the assassination]] Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman [[Maria Zakharova]] said: "Terrorism will not pass. We will fight it decisively."<ref name="WP1219">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/gunfire-wounds-russian-ambassador-in-turkey-reports-say/2016/12/19/ae32d1c8-c608-11e6-85b5-76616a33048d_story.html|title=Russian ambassador to Turkey assassinated in Ankara by off-duty police officer |website=Washington Post|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref> President Vladimir Putin stated he believes "a crime has been committed and it was without doubt a provocation aimed at spoiling the normalization of Russo-Turkish relations and spoiling the Syrian peace process which is being actively pushed by Russia, Turkey, Iran and others". He also ordered heightening of security measures at Russian embassies worldwide, and stated that "we need to know who guided the hand of the murderer".<ref name="WP1219" /><ref>{{cite web |last1=Osborn |first1=Andrew|last2=Pomeroy|first2=Robin|title=Putin says ambassador murder is ploy to wreck Syrian peace process |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-russia-diplomat-putin-idUSKBN1482B3|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=19 December 2016 |date=19 December 2016}}</ref> <!--Please read the talk page discussion before adding reactions to this section--> {{-}}

[[File:BMBallHarpers.jpg|thumb|right|400px|The Bradley-Martin Ball by Harry Whitney McVickar]] The '''Bradley-Martin Ball''' was a lavish [[Costume party|costume ball]] at the [[Waldorf-Astoria Hotel|Waldorf Hotel]] in [[New York City]] on the night of February 10, 1897. Cornelia Bradley-Martin, wife of [[Bradley Martin]], organized the ball, with the intention of making it "the greatest party in the history of the city". Eight hundred [[socialite]]s spent about $400,000 imitating kings and queens.<ref name="FTMartin">{{cite book |title= Things I Remember (1913) |last= Martin |first= Frederick Townsend |authorlink=Frederick Townsend Martin |coauthors= |year= 1913 |publisher= John Lane Company |location= New York |isbn= 0-548-83545-4 |pages= 280–285}}</ref> Bradley-Martin's stated intention was to create an economic stimulus for New York City, which was at the end of the [[Long Depression]] which began in 1873 and included the [[Panic of 1893]]. The Bradley-Martins spent approximately $9.7 million in today's money to throw the ball. Across the country, preachers and editorial writers argued over the propriety of a party that would cost hundreds of thousands of dollars. In the end, the ball was a social triumph but created negative publicity.<ref name="McGerr">McGerr, Michael. ''A Fierce Discontent''. [[Oxford University Press]], Inc. NY, pages 4-6, 2003.</ref>
== Before the Ball == In the three weeks leading up to it, New York society made the ball its one topic of discussion. The ''Commercial Advertiser'' exclaimed: "There is a great stir today in fashionable circles and even in public circles. The cause of it all is the Bradley Martin ball, beside which the [[Olney–Pauncefote Treaty|arbitration treaty]], [[Cuban War of Independence|the Cuban question]], and the [[Lexow Committee|Lexow investigation]] seem to have become secondary matters of public interest."<ref name="yodelout">{{cite web |title=Waldorf-Astoria – Famous Dinners, Balls, And Guests |url=https://new-york-city.yodelout.com/waldorf-astoria-famous-dinners-balls-and-guests/ |website=new-york-city.yodelout.com |accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref>
The guests included: [[Caroline Webster Schermerhorn Astor]], known simply as Mrs. Astor, costumed as [[Mary, Queen of Scots]], her son [[John Jacob Astor IV|John Jacob Astor]] as [[Henry IV of France]] and his wife as [[Marie Antoinette]],<ref name="RHutto">{{cite journal |last=Hutto |first=Richard Jay |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=February 1997 |title=The Party of the Century |journal=Quest |volume= |issue= |pages=52–57 |id= |url= |accessdate= |quote= }}</ref> [[James L. Breese]] as the [[Duke of Guise]], [[John Pierpont Morgan]], Charles Childs as [[Lady Teazle]], [[Hermann Oelrichs]] as a Dutch Bergomaster, [[Charles Post]] as [[Madame de Maintenon]], [[Stanford White]] in a Court costume of black velvet and white satin, the artist [[Adolfo Müller-Ury]] as a Spanish toreador, [[Pierpont Morgan]] as [[Louise of Mecklenburg-Strelitz]], and Hamilton Fish Webster as [[Maria Theresa of Austria]].<ref name="Febseventh"/>
==The Ball== [[File:JamesLBreese BMBall.jpg|thumb|right |James L. Breese dressed as the Duke of Guise in white corded silk with embroidery of pearls and silver lace.]] === Concept === Cornelia Bradley-Martin’s idea was to give a costume ball at so short notice that her guests would not have time to get their dresses from [[Paris]], and instead support local businesses.<ref name="FTMartin"/> This overlapped with the idea that it was much better for the laboring people if the wealthy spent their money locally instead of taking it to [[Europe]].<ref name="Febfourth">{{cite news |title=TALKED ON THE COMING BALL. Mr. Gunton Thinks the Rich Should Spend Their Money Here. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1897/02/04/102398950.pdf |accessdate=30 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 4, 1897}}</ref>
The Reverend Dr. Rainsford believed in the rich giving money to be distributed as charity, whereas others, including the members of the [[Musical Mutual Protective Union]] (MMPU), disagreed. They believed in the wealthy spending their wealth in enjoying themselves, and thus giving hundreds and thousands of working people an opportunity to earn money and maintain their self-respect instead of having to accept charity. The MMPU became indignant when they heard that the Marine Band was to be at the ball instead of musicians from their union. The members of the Marine Band did not urgently need the money that they were going to receive from the ball.<ref name="Janthirtieth">{{cite news |title=MUSICIANS ARE INDIGNANT. They Hear that the Marine Band Is to be at the Bradley-Martin Ball, and Condemn Dr. Rainsford. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1897/01/30/102398699.pdf |accessdate=30 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 30, 1897}}</ref>
=== Preparations === [[Florist]] Small was in charge of the decorations for the Bradley-Martin ball. Decorating the Waldorf began on the morning of February 9 by A.W. Merritt, Small’s colleague. In the days leading up to the event, dealers’ stocks and household stores were ransacked to supply the demand for ornaments and historical accuracy. All the jewelers who dealt in antiques were cleaned out of all they had on hand. Jewels held as [[heirloom]]s by the old families of New York were taken from safety vaults. Laces that had been locked away in family chests or in safe deposit vaults for long years had been retrieved.<ref name="Febninth">{{cite news |title=THE BRADLEY MARTIN BALL {{!}} A Wealth of Heirlooms in Antique Jewels and Rare Old Laces, to be Shown. {{!}} PRICELESS FAMILY TREASURES. {{!}} Dealers' Stocks and Household Stores Ransacked and Exhausted to Supply the Demand for Ornaments and Historical Accuracy. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1897/02/09/102399244.pdf |accessdate=30 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 9, 1897}}</ref>
Twelve hundred invitations were issued for the event, and more than half of those invited were in attendance. Some who did come also left early, seeming to have made an appearance out of curiosity.<ref name="Febeleventh">{{cite news |title=BRADLEY MARTIN BALL {{!}} Not so Many Guests Attended the Function at The Waldorf as Had Been Expected. {{!}} THE SCENE IN THE HANDSOMELY DECKED DANCING ROOM. {{!}} Those Who Took Part in the Exhibition Dances — Some of the Guests and Their Costumes — The Supper and Decorations. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1897/02/11/100419295.pdf |accessdate=30 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 11, 1897}}</ref>
=== The Waldorf === "The interior of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was transformed into a replica of Versailles, and rare tapestries, beautiful flowers and countless lights made an effective background for the wonderful gowns and their wearers."<ref name = "FTMartin"/>
Police officers stood guard at the entrance to the Waldorf. The Bradley-Martins arrived first at 10:15 pm. At half past 10 a group of carriages arrived and before 11 the stream of guests had become continuous. The guests were ushered into the Waldorf, whereupon they ascended to the corridors on the second floor where 15 dressing rooms were available for the use and comfort of the guests.<ref name="Febeleventh"/><ref name="Febtenth">{{cite news |title=THE BRADLEY MARTIN FETE The Waldorf Yesterday Given up to the Decorators and to Rehearsals of the Dances. THE SEARCH FOR HEIRLOOMS. All Outside Windows to be Boarded Up — All the Spare Rooms Secured by the Guests — Arrangements to Photograph the Costumes. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1897/02/10/105942086.pdf |accessdate=30 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 10, 1897}}</ref> Some guests, preferring not to expose themselves on the street while wearing tempting fortunes in jewels and laces, changed into their costumes at this point. This wasn’t done through any feeling of fear, but merely as a wise precaution.<ref name="Febninth"/> Wigmakers and make-up artists were available in these rooms. When leaving the dressing rooms the guests headed to the smaller ballroom. It was here where Cornelia Bradley-Martin received her guests. A lackey announced the guests’ names and the characters they impersonated to her. This stream of guests poured by her for nearly 90 minutes and it was after midnight before she was able to enter the main ballroom to take her place in the opening ''quadrille d’honneur''.<ref name="Febeleventh"/>[[File:MrsBradleyMartincameo.jpg|thumb | right | A Cameo of Cornelia Bradley-Martin dressed as Mary Stuart, Queen of Scots, for the Ball.]]
=== Costumes === Cornelia Bradley-Martin requested her guests to pick something from the 16th, 17th, or 18th centuries, and some came dressed as [[George Washington]], a Japanese nobleman, an Egyptian princess and [[Pocahontas]]. A list was compiled and published in the ''New York Times'' three days prior to the event, listing guests and the historical characters they were going to impersonate and what costumes they were going to wear.<ref name="Febseventh">{{cite news |title=THE BRADLEY MARTIN BALL; Preparations Nearly Completed for an Entertainment in Society Which Promises to be Historic. DECORATIONS AND COSTUMES. The Career of the Host and Hostess in New York Society -- Previous Successes in Entertaining -- Some Fancy Balls of the Past. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1897/02/07/archives/the-bradley-martin-ball-preparations-nearly-completed-for-an.html |accessdate=30 July 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 7, 1897}}</ref> Bradley-Martin "personated [[Mary, Queen of Scots|Mary Stuart]], and her gold embroidered gown was trimmed with pearls and precious stones worth more than $60,000.<ref name="yodelout"/> Bradley (Martin), as [[Louis XV]], wore a Court suit of brocade".<ref name = "FTMartin"/> "In many cases the diamond buttons worn by the men represented thousands of dollars, and the value of the historic gems worn by the ladies baffles description."<ref name = "FTMartin"/> At the time, the average income of an American was $400 a year.<ref name="yodelout"/>
[[Otho Cushing]], a young artist from Boston, created quite a stir when he appeared as an Italian falconer's costume which consisted of full body tights, a short jacket and a cap with a stuffed falcon on one arm. "The costume left little to the imagination as far as the figure was concerned, and, although historically correct in every detail, was so decidedly pronounced that he made a sensation wherever he moved."<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title= Echoes of the Big Ball {{!}} Society People Still Gossipping Over Beautiful Surroundings and Pleasant Hours While Guests of the Bradley Martins. END JUST BEFORE DAYLIGHT. Mr. and Mrs. Martin Left the Waldorf About 6 o'Clock — Getting the Guests to Their Carriages — Clearing Away the Evidences of the Ball — Some Guests Excited Comment on Physical Effects — The Police Criticised. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1897/02/12/105942208.pdf |work= |publisher= New York Times|date= February 12, 1897|accessdate=2008-06-27 }}</ref>
=== Decorations === The smaller ballroom was set throughout with furniture of the [[Louis XV]] period, and the walls were hung with tapestry draperies. [[Rose]]s were hurled en masse against the draperies and let remain where they landed. The side of the room, where the Hungarian band was placed, was concealed by long-stemmed roses and garlands were dropped from the center to each side and over the mirrors.<ref name="Febeleventh"/> The Hungarian Band, under the leadership of Carl Berlinger, played 12 concert selections, chosen by Mrs. Bradley-Martin, throughout the evening.<ref name="Febseventh"/>
Upon entering the grand ballroom the guests faced a wall in which 15 mirrors were imbedded. The far side of the room, the musicians’ balcony, was concealed by pink roses, with garlands also hanging from above. There were over 5,000 roses and 3,000 [[orchids]] in these various groupings.<ref name="Febeleventh"/>
The café and the court were also decorated, with a desired homelike effect.<ref name="Febeleventh"/> 125 tables were set up, each to accommodate six guests, with a centerpiece of Beauty roses.<ref name="Febseventh"/>
=== Music === The ''danse d’honneur'', arranged by Caroline Astor, opened the ball. The company was led by Cornelia Bradley-Martin, in the role of the Queen, escorted by John Jacob Astor as the King. For this danse d’honneur, the orchestra played music composed by Beethoven. Following this, the orchestra started playing one of [[Chopin|Chopin’s]] [[polonaises]] announcing the approach of the wife of Edmund L. Baylies and her associates for the [[minuet]]. When they formed for the minuet the orchestra struck into [[Mozart|Mozart’s]] dance music out of "[[Don Giovanni]]". The dance of the debutantes was next, and it was livelier than the others and the most difficult of all. The members of this set, organized by the wife of Frederic Bronson, danced a Hungarian Court quadrille, the Kormagyar, in music arranged by Allen Dodworth.<ref name="Febeleventh"/> This quadrille ended the exhibition dances. General dancing followed the three quadrilles until supper time.<ref name="Febseventh"/>
=== Supper === [[File:RECEPTION AND BALL (held by) MRS. BRADLEY MARTIN (at) "22 WEST 20TH ST. NEW YORK, NY" (PRIVATE HOME) (NYPL Hades-270063-474713).tiff|thumb|right]] "Between the grand ballroom and the cafe, used on this occasion for the supper room, is a barricade of windows, which were thrown open about 1 o'clock in the morning, and the guests were then at liberty to enjoy the delights of the cuisine. The menu was as follows: *CHAUD **Consommé de Volaille **Bouillon de Clovis **Homard à la Newburg **Huitres à la Viennoise **Poularde farcie aux truffes **Filet de Boeuf Jardinière **Terrapene désossée à la Baltimore **Canard canvasback *FROID **Galantine à la Victoria **Terrine de Foie Gras **Cailles piquées à la Gelce **Chaud-froid de Pluviers **Jambon en Danier **Mayonnaise de Volaille *ENTREMETS DE DOUCEUR **Gelée aux Fruits **Gauffres Chantilly **Gâteaux Madeleine **Biscuits glacés, Fatma **Sorbet fin de Siècle **Tutti-Frutti **Café Parfait **Plombière aux Marrons **Glaces de Fantaisie **Petits Fours. Fruits, Bonbons **Café"[http://thehistorybox.com/ny_city/society/articles/nycity_society_balls_dances_article00236.htm]
=== Entertainment and Favors === The [[cotillion]] commenced at three, and spectators found amusement as the gentlemen danced it with swords at their sides. Swords got tangled in gowns and laces, and courtiers tripped over them, to the delight of the spectators. [[Elisha Dyer, Jr.]] led the cotillion.<ref name="Febeleventh"/>
Cornelia Bradley-Martin selected small silver figures and a staff as “favors” for each of the guests of the ball. The “favors” were awarded by Elisha Dyer, Jr. as leader of the cotillion.<ref name="Febeleventh"/>
== Reaction and Controversy == Before the Ball took place, the [[Bradley-Martins]] drew fire from all directions, as newspapers criticized its extravagance and clergymen urged their congregations not to attend. One clergyman denounced the ball by saying: "You rich people put next to nothing in the collection plate, and yet you’ll spend thousands of dollars on Mrs. Bradley-Martin’s ball”.<ref name="FTMartin"/>
After the ball many ministers preached against its excessive consumption and the authorities promptly raised Bradley-Martin’s taxes (as well as those of their friends and fellow-attendees the Astors) quite out of proportion to those paid by anyone else. The Bradley-Martins returned to England, where they had owned a home for several years, and Scotland, where they leased a {{convert|65000|acre|km2|sing=on}} estate, Balmacaan.<ref name="RHutto"/>
Although historians have repeated oft-told half-truths without conducting primary research, the Bradley-Martin ball is perhaps best-remembered as the end of the excesses of the [[Gilded Age]].<ref name="Beard2009">{{cite book |last1=Beard |first1=Patricia |title=After the Ball |date=2009 |publisher=Xlibris Corporation |isbn=9781524526375 |page=139 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=icxgDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT139 |accessdate=30 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="Conlin2008">{{cite book |last1=Conlin |first1=Joseph R. |title=The American Past: A Survey of American History, Enhanced Edition |date=2008 |publisher=Cengage Learning |isbn=0495566225 |page=82 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Mm6r3lOY5gC&pg=PR82 |accessdate=30 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
==See also== {{commons}} *[[Duchess of Richmond's ball]]
== Notes == {{reflist}}
==External links== *The Bradley Martin Ball 2-10-1897, TheHistoryBox.com, Source: The New York Times, February 11, 1897 [http://thehistorybox.com/ny_city/society/articles/nycity_society_balls_dances_article00236.htm] *Waldorf-Astoria- Famous Dinners and Balls [http://www.oldandsold.com/articles08/waldorf-astoria-10.shtml]

American hostages released |combatant1= {{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Colombia]] |combatant2={{flagicon|Panama}} [[Panama]]nian [[Rebels]] |combatant3={{flagicon|United States|1863}} [[United States]] |combatant4= |commander1= {{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Rafael Núñez (politician)|Rafael Núñez]]

1 [[Steamboat|steamer]] |strength4= |casualties1= |casualties2= |casualties3= |casualties4= |notes='''Casualties''' 18 killed }} The '''Burning of Colón''', or the '''Panama Incident''', was a major event of the [[Colombian Civil War of 1885|Colombian Civil War in 1885]]. [[Panama]]nian rebels loyal to [[Pedro Prestan]] destroyed the city by committing [[arson]] before retreating after a battle with federal [[Colombia]]n troops. The episode also included a landing by [[United States]] [[US Navy|Navy]] sailors and [[United States Marine Corps|marines]] from two warships after the rebels seized American citizens.{{cite web|url=http://bruceruiz.net/PanamaHistory/burning_of_colon_by_pedro_presta.htm|title=Burning of Colon by Pedro Prestan|website=bruceruiz.net}}Appletons', pg.44–46 ==Incident== In the late 1800s Colombia's political situation was in turmoil as revolution and riots plagued the country. In 1885 another revolution began which spilled into the [[Isthmus of Panama]]. On or about March 16 the rebel leader Pedro Prestan occupied the small port of [[Colón, Panama|Colón]] on the [[Gulf Coast]] where he was waiting for a shipment of weapons by the American merchant ship ''Colon'' of the [[Pacific Mail Steamship Company]]. On March 26, [[Captain (nautical)|Captain]] [[John M. Dow]], representing the Pacific Mail Steamship Company in Colon, received a letter from the Panamanian sub-[[Secretary of State]] informing him that the offloading of any weapons intended for rebels was strictly prohibited. On the following day, Captain Dow received another letter from [[Secretary General]] Gomina which advised that he had assumed the position of commander-in-chief of civil and military affairs and should any of the weapons be removed from the ''Colon'' then the agent responsible for their delivery might attempt to seek asylum from the American or [[France|French]] naval forces present. Dow then informed the United States [[consul (representative)|consul]] Mr. Wright who relayed orders from the consul-general Mr. Adamson not to allow any weapons to be offloaded without the permission of the consulate or Captain [[Theodore Kane]] of the [[Steamboat|steamer]] [[USS Galena (1880)|USS ''Galena'']], which happened to be in port at the time. So on March 29, when the ''Colon'' arrived at Colon with fifty-two packages marked "M", Captain Dow assumed command and ordered that nothing be taken off the ship. This angered Pedro Prestan when he came to pick up his delivery and Dow and three others were then taken under arrest by [[militia]]men, one of the captives was a United States Navy [[lieutenant]] named Judd. When Captain Kane learned of the arrests, negotiations began between the two parties. Prestan wanted his guns and the Kane wanted the American citizens to be released but the captain could not use force as it meant risking the lives of the prisoners. Rebel forces included at least 100 men, around twenty of whom accompanied Prestan at all times and fortified a small position within the city streets. The remaining men were based outside of town at [[Monkey Hill]]. The rebels had an old [[cannon]] as well and threatened to open fire on the ''Galena'' if she came in towards the shore. Prestan also declared that if he was forced to retreat, he would destroy the city with [[dynamite]]. For several hours, until the next day, the negotiations proceeded and the Americans refused to give Prestan the cargo of weapons. Meanwhile, Captain Dow and the other prisoners were taken to the Panamanian base to be executed by a [[firing squad]]. Soon after Mr. Right ordered that the weapons be given up as it was the only means of releasing the hostages. Unknowingly, Captain Kane was distracting the rebels while the [[Colombian Army]] approached Colon. Eventually Prestan became alarmed and supposedly ordered his men to begin burning the city but it was later determined that he never gave such order; each party blamed the other for starting the fire, for which Prestán was hanged and later absolved by "resolución No. 101-30-48 de 24 de Septiembre").{{cite web|url=http://laestrella.com.pa/opinion/columnistas/125-anos-ahorcamiento-pedro-prestan/23715372|title=A 125 años del ahorcamiento de Pedro Prestán|date=19 August 2010|publisher=}} Shortly thereafter the Colombians launched their attack. For a few hours the Panamanians held their position while the city burned around them until they were finally routed during the last Colombian charge. A detachment of about 100 marines and sailors from the ''Galena'' then landed at the request of the Colombian government and 600 more men and two cannons from the [[USS Tennessee (1865)|USS ''Tennessee'']] arrived within the next few days. [[Admiral]] [[James Edward Jouett]] assumed command of American forces which was tasked with protecting American property. This was hard because the fire quickly spread throughout Colon, causing great damage. Several of the destroyed buildings were American or [[Europe]]an owned and damages amounted to the millions though compensation was never paid.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1885/04/22/archives/affairs-on-the-isthmus-graphic-account-of-outrages-by-panama.html | work=The New York Times | title=Affairs On The Isthmus; Graphic Account Of Outrages By Panama Insurgents | date=April 22, 1885}} Colon burned for days and the American [[garrison]] withdrew without doing much to save the city. United States citizens were also evacuated along with other foreign nationals. The American government responded to the incident by sending men to [[United States occupation of Panama (1885)|occupy]] both Colon, for a second time, and the city of [[Panama City|Panama]]. There were no American casualties but between the Panamanians and the Colombians, eighteen people were killed and many more were wounded in action or hurt by the fire. ==References== {{reflist}} *{{DANFS|http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/g1/galena-ii.htm}} *{{cite book |last=|first= |author2=|edition= |title=Appletons' annual cyclopaedia and register of important events, Volume 11 |year=1887 |publisher=D. Appleton & Co. |location=Harvard University |isbn=}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Burning of Colon}} [[Category:History of Panama]] [[Category:United States Navy in the 19th century]] [[Category:History of Colombia]] [[Category:Colombia–United States relations]] [[Category:Gulf of Mexico]] [[Category:Naval operations and battles]] [[Category:Combat incidents|Colon]] [[Category:Punitive expeditions of the United States]] [[Category:March 1885 events]] [[Category:April 1885 events]]
