Because this was the first large-scale survey in this field, comparisons could not made. The government of Fukushima Prefecture provided the results of the testing and a list of the patients to the panel, which it had previously refused to do in order to protect the privacy of the patients.<ref>The Mainichi Shimbun (06 June 2013)[http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20130606p2a00m0na013000c.html 4 members leave Fukushima panel overseeing prefectural health survey] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130611010711/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20130606p2a00m0na013000c.html |date=2013-06-11 }}</ref><ref>The Asahi Shimbun (06 June 2013)[http://ajw.asahi.com/article/0311disaster/fukushima/AJ201306060092 Experts: More data needed to assess radiation's role in cancer among Fukushima kids] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130612230326/http://ajw.asahi.com/article/0311disaster/fukushima/AJ201306060092 |date=2013-06-12 }}</ref>
==Testing school lunches== On the end of March 2012 a survey of [[Kyodo News]] revealed that fears for contamination with radioactive fallout 44 of 74 major towns in Japan were testing school lunches or food-components for radioactive cesium. In eastern Japan a majority of 34 out of 42 towns had started with these tests, after the government had ordered testing in 17 prefectures around the Fukushima-plant.
In other parts of Japan, testing was left free to decide whether to test school lunches. But already 10 out of 32 towns had implemented similar tests, while at this date [[Morioka]], [[Akita, Akita|Akita]] and four other towns had plans to start testing. Some cities did not test themselves, they relied on the safety of the food because pre-shipment tests conducted by producers.
Although after 1 April 2012 the Japanese government lowered the legal standard for radioactive cesium-levels down to 100 becquerels/kg, some cities decided to lower the standard even further:
* no detection : [[Tottori, Tottori|Tottori]] * 4 becquerels/kg: [[Sapporo]] * 10 becquerels/kg:[[Yamagata, Yamagata|Yamagata]] * 40 becquerels/kg: [[Fukui, Fukui|Fukui]], [[Adachi, Tokyo|Adachi]], [[Sumida, Tokyo|Sumida]] * 50 becquerels/kg: [[Kyoto]]
Other towns like [[Fukushima, Fukushima|Fukushima]], [[Matsuyama]] and the Bunkyo Ward school in Tokyo planned to demand for lower than legal levels.<ref>The Mainichi Shimbun (29 March 2012)[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20120329p2g00m0dm006000c.html 44 Japanese municipalities test school lunches for cesium] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120330122005/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20120329p2g00m0dm006000c.html |date=2012-03-30 }}</ref>
==Stress-tests== On 8 November the Japanese government published the first results of nuclear safety tests at the website of [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency|NISA]]. This was done to boost transparency before laid-off reactors were restarted. The minister of industry Yukio Edano asked the public to respond with remarks and questions about the tests, and promised to respond to this all. He hoped, that this would lead to a better understanding of the nuclear safety procedures.<ref>NHK-world (8 November 2011) [http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/08_18.html Govt releases nuclear safety test results] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903050208/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/08_18.html |date=2011-09-03 }}</ref>
==Debris disposal== Nine months after the disaster of 11 March it proved increasingly difficult to dispose all the debris and rubble. In April 572 municipalities were willing to accept the debris, but in the latest survey done by the Ministry of Environment on 7 October only 54 municipalities in 11 prefectures were willing to consider acceptance, and only six places had already taken in parts of the debris. Fear for radioactive contamination was thought to be the cause for this. The ministry declined to identify the municipalities that have agreed, or refused, to accept the debris. Some 4.88 million tons of rubble were needed to be disposed of a year after the quake. Around 20.5 million tons was collected in Iwate and Miyagi, all was stored at multiple temporary storage sites. The debris from Fukushima would be stored within this prefecture. On 2 November 30 tons of debris was loaded on train, and sent to Tokyo by rail from the city of Miyako, Iwate. The first train carrying the debris would arrive in Tokyo on 4 November. This made Tokyo the first local government outside Japan's northeast to accept debris.<ref>The Mainichi Daily News (3 November 2011) [http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/national/archive/news/2011/11/03/20111103p2g00m0dm016000c.html Municipalities increasingly unwilling to accept quake debris] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120711012217/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/national/archive/news/2011/11/03/20111103p2g00m0dm016000c.html |date=2012-07-11 }}</ref><ref>JAIF (3 November 2011)[http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1320374709P.pdf Earthquake-report 255] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103124954/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1320374709P.pdf |date=2012-01-03 }}</ref>
===Interim Storage facility=== On 28 December at a meeting in the city of Fukushima minister Goshi Hosono asked the local leaders of prefecture Fukushima for permission to build an interim storage facility somewhere in the county of [[Futaba District, Fukushima|Futaba]] near the two villages hosting the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant.
Local residents, however, were seriously divided. Those who would like to return to their houses, were afraid, that an interim-storage might prove to be a very permanent storage, and would make any return impossible. But others had already accepted the fact, that the radiation-levels around their former houses would be too high, and would make living there impractical for a long time. Some local residents realized that without the interim storage facility, there would no place to dispose radioactive waste at all, and the construction of the facility would create also new jobs.
Local leaders were willing to accept the new waste-storage, but in the mean time they were reluctant, because the anger of some of their citizens and the fact that the presence of it, could hamper all efforts to decontaminate the area and would make repopulation impossible. Therefor they requested an insurance from the government, that the storage would be closed after 30 years.<ref>The Mainichi Daily news (29 December 2011) [http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111229p2a00m0na004000c.html Gov't request for nuclear storage facility site sends shockwaves through Fukushima] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111229185933/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111229p2a00m0na004000c.html |date=2011-12-29 }}</ref><ref>JAIF (29 December 2011)[http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1325129913P.pdf earthquake report 303: Govt requests sites for waste soil storage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103155038/http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/ENGNEWS01_1325129913P.pdf |date=2012-01-03 }}</ref>
==Public reaction== The news of the contamination of foods with radioactive substances leaking from the Fukushima nuclear reactors damaged the mutual trust between local food producers including farmers and consumers. Everywhere in Japan banners and stickers were found with: "Hang in there, Fukushima!", numerous harmful rumors on Fukushima products could be found online. Many rumors that were discriminatory to Fukushima and other messages slandering Fukushima people could be found on the Internet. The source of cesium was found to be rice straw that had been feed to the animal. But a notice of the Japanese government that was sent to cattle-farmers after the nuclear accident made no mention to the possibility that rice straw could be contaminated with radioactive materials from the plant.<ref>The Mainichi Daily News( 25 October 2011) [http://mdn.mainichi.jp/perspectives/news/20111025p2a00m0na005000c.html Nuclear plant accidents threaten relations between food producers and consumers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111026193240/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/perspectives/news/20111025p2a00m0na005000c.html |date=2011-10-26 }}</ref>
Media coverage of the event has been described as taking an "irrational approach which generated the worst of humanity" because many anti-nuclear groups tried to make political points out of the issue. In addition, the main story should have been on the 19,000 people killed by the tsunami and the thousands of missing individuals. However, public attention was drawn ''away'' from the needs of major restructuring, housing, developing the transportation system, and helping people who suffered because of the tsunami.<ref>[http://moderntokyotimes.com/2012/03/02/fukushima-nuclear-accident-the-media-and-international-responses/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313194222/http://moderntokyotimes.com/2012/03/02/fukushima-nuclear-accident-the-media-and-international-responses/ |date=March 13, 2012 }}</ref>
[[David Spiegelhalter]] of Cambridge University explained that the psychological effects of the media coverage include increased feelings of risk and vulnerability.<ref>[http://www.sciencewise-erc.org.uk/cms/risk-and-public-dialogue-in-the-fukushima-story/ Risk and public dialogue in the Fukushima story]. Sciencewise-erc.org.uk (2011-03-18). Retrieved on 2015-05-14.</ref> Others have warned of harmful psychological consequences of such coverage.<ref>[https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn20843-fukushima-media-coverage-may-be-harmful.html Fukushima media coverage 'may be harmful' – health – 30 August 2011]. New Scientist (2011-08-30). Retrieved on 2015-05-14.</ref> Researchers from King’s College London’s Institute of Psychiatry and the Behavioural Science team at the Health Protection Agency (HPA) found that a third of people experienced high levels of anger, anxiety, and distress.<ref>[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/iop/news/records/2012/September/Fukushima-.aspx King's College London – Uncertainty and psychological impact of Fukushima]. Kcl.ac.uk (2012-09-21). Retrieved on 2015-05-14.</ref> The German media in particular, has been accused of scaremongering and misleading the public on the safety of nuclear power.<ref>[http://theeuropean-magazine.com/257-martin-ralph/258-fukushimas-media-coverage ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120022415/http://theeuropean-magazine.com/257-martin-ralph/258-fukushimas-media-coverage |date=January 20, 2013 }}</ref>
==Judicial actions against restarting nuclear powerplants== In August 2011 citizens of the prefecture [[Shiga]], at the banks of Lake [[Biwa]], started a lawsuit at the Otsu District Court, and asked a court order to prevent the restart of seven reactors operated by [[Kansai Electric Power Company]], in the prefecture [[Fukui Prefecture|Fukui]].
On 8 November 2011 a group of 40 citizens of [[Ōtsu, Shiga|Otsu]] prefecture [[Kyodo]] started a similar lawsuit at the Otsu District Court against [[Japan Atomic Power Company]]. They asked for a provisional court order to delay the restart of the two reactors at the [[Tsuruga Nuclear Power Plant]] in the city of [[Tsuruga]]. The plaintiffs argued that:
* Lake [[Biwa]] could be contaminated when a nuclear accident would occur at the plant * The whole region of Kansai is dependent on this, the biggest lake of Japan, because it is the source of drinking water for the whole region * an accident would endanger the health of all residents * the Tsuruga plant is built on a site with a fault below it and a severe accident could occur during an earthquake * the No. 1 reactor had been more than 40 years in service since it was first operational in 1970, and the Tsuruga plant was insufficiently protected against tsunamis. * the ongoing regular checks were done under the government's safety and technological standards, and the nuclear crisis in Fukushima had proven that those regulations were insufficient. * the reactors should remain shut down until the cause of the disaster in Fukushima would be fully investigated * the regular checks should be performed under the new safety standards.
The operator of the plant did not want to make any comment to the press. At that time the two reactors of the plant were shut down for regular checkups. But the four-month inspection of the No. 2 reactor could be completed in December, and the checkup of reactor 1 could be completed in March 2012.<ref>The Mainichi Daily News (9 November 2011) [http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111109p2g00m0dm007000c.html Residents seek court order not to restart Tsuruga reactors] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111112080134/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111109p2g00m0dm007000c.html |date=2011-11-12 }}</ref>
On 27 December 2011 a lawsuit was started against [[Kyūshū Electric Power Company]] by 290 local residents. Most of them living in the prefectures [[Saga Prefecture|Saga]] and [[Fukuoka Prefecture|Fukuoka]]. They said that the disaster in Fukushima had made it clear, that an accident at the Genkai-plant caused by a possible earthquake or tsunami could damage the lives and health of the people living nearby. They questioned in particular the safety of the 36-year-old nr. 1 reactor near the sea. Kyushu Electric commented, that it would examine the suit and would act "appropriately." This was already the third time that locals tried to stop this plant. Because in July 2011 90 people asked the local court for an injunction order to stop the nr. 2 and nr. 3 Genkai-reactors from going back online, like was done in August 2010 when about 130 local residents and others demanded from the district court to halt to the use of plutonium-uranium mixed oxide fuel, or MOX, at the No. 3 Genkai-reactor.<ref>The Mainichi Daily News (28 December 2011) [http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111228p2g00m0dm015000c.html Residents sue to seek complete suspension of Genkai reactors] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120104032224/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111228p2g00m0dm015000c.html |date=2012-01-04 }}</ref>
In January 2012 a lawsuit was filed against the Japanese government and Kyushu Electric Power Co. at the Saga District Court by about 1,700 people from all over Japan. The complaint mentioned that after the Fukushima disaster the safety myth regarding nuclear reactors was proven to be false, and under the Japanese Constitution everybody in Japan should live without fear. On 12 March 2012 the total of people complaining was already more than 3000, when 1370 people joined the plaintiffs. Another group was planning to file another suit to seek suspension of yet another nuclear power plant run by the same company. According to Akira Hasegawa, the leader of the plaintiffs and former president of Saga University it looked possible to him raising the number of plaintiffs to 10.000.<ref>The Mainichi Shimbun (13 March 2012) [http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20120313p2g00m0dm027000c.html Lawsuit seeking to halt Genkai atomic plant draws record plaintiffs] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120711103128/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20120313p2g00m0dm027000c.html |date=2012-07-11 }}</ref>
===Criminal charges against NISA, NSA and TEPCO=== On 14 March 2012 two groups of citizens had taken up the plan to file criminal complaints against officials of TEPCO and governmental agencies for professional negligence in the Fukushima nuclear disaster. On 9 March in the town of Iwaki they had held a demonstration to mobilize at least 1000 people in the area of Fukushima to join in, because round 15 May the complaint would be filed at the office of the Fukushima District Public Prosecutors. In this complaint officials of the governmental Nuclear Safety Commission of Japan, [[Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency|NISA]] and TEPCO would be accused of criminal conduct and neglect resulting in the failure to prevent the nuclear crisis.
As a result, many people were exposed to radiation, patients dies because they needed to flee from their hospital, The group considered to accuse the officials of imposing health hazards through the spread of massive amounts of radioactive substances.
The 58-year-old member of the Iwaki municipal assembly and leader of the group, Kazuyoshi Sato said, he believed it was "nonsense that nobody has been held criminally responsible for causing a major nuclear accident. I'd like to call on as many Fukushima people as possible, including those who are taking shelter in areas outside of the prefecture, to join our action."
According to lawyer Yukuo Yasuda in the complaint TEPCO would be charged for not taking all necessary precautions against a possible tsunami, although studies had pointed out that there had been this kind of tsunamis in this region in the past. NISA and NSA were accused of neglect because they did not instruct TEPCO to implement the necessary measures.<ref>The Mainichi Shimbun (15 March 2012)[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20120315p2g00m0dm010000c.html Fukushima citizens to accuse TEPCO, state of negligence over crisis]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Criminal investigations== On 22 May 2012 the 33-year-old Makoto Owada, a high-ranking gang-member of the Sumiyoshi-kai yakuza group was arrested. Workers supplied by a network of companies and subcontractors were forced to pay substantial portions of their earnings to the subcontracting companies and Owada. Investigators learned that already in 2007 Owada was dispatching workers at the nuclear power plant construction sites in various areas. According to the police, it was needed to cut off all gang-funding, to prevent the flow of tax-money to yakuza-gangs.<ref>the Mainichi Shimbun (23 May 2012) [http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20120523p2a00m0na017000c.html Portion of wages paid to some Fukushima plant workers may have gone to gang: police] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120526113631/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20120523p2a00m0na017000c.html |date=2012-05-26 }}</ref>
==Scientific reaction== On 25 October 2011 the university of [[Hiroshima]] disclosed a plan to train the staff of the Japan Red Cross staff in how to respond to nuclear disasters like the one in Fukushima. The papers were to be signed on 26 October 2011. The president Toshimasa Asahara of the University said, he hoped that the university staff would also learn from the experience of the Red Cross in the care for disaster-disasters, including those in other countries. The University of Hiroshima University did establish a leading research center into the effects of radiation on the human body and health: the [[Research Institute for Radiation, Biology and Medicine, Hiroshima|Research Institute for Radiation, Biology and Medicine]], due to decades lasting studies after the effects on local population, that survived the atomic-explosion of Hiroshima in 1945.<ref>The Mainichi Daily News (26 October 2011) [http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111026p2g00m0dm011000c.html Hiroshima Univ., Red Cross to cooperate in radiation, disaster fields] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111030024453/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111026p2g00m0dm011000c.html |date=2011-10-30 }}</ref>
The Fukushima accident exposed some troubling nuclear safety issues:<ref name=Sci11/> <blockquote> Despite the resources poured into analyzing crustal movements and having expert committees determine earthquake risk, for instance, researchers never considered the possibility of a magnitude-9 earthquake followed by a massive tsunami. The failure of multiple safety features on nuclear power plants has raised questions about the nation's engineering prowess. Government flip-flopping on acceptable levels of radiation exposure confused the public, and health professionals provided little guidance. Facing a dearth of reliable information on radiation levels, citizens armed themselves with dosimeters, pooled data, and together produced radiological contamination maps far more detailed than anything the government or official scientific sources ever provided.<ref name=Sci11>{{cite web |url=http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2011/11/in-wake-of-fukushima-disaster.html |title=In Wake of Fukushima Disaster, Japan's Scientists Ponder How to Regain Public Trust |author=Dennis Normile |date=28 November 2011 |work=Science |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111128195939/http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2011/11/in-wake-of-fukushima-disaster.html |archivedate=28 November 2011 |df= }}</ref> </blockquote>
==Financial liability== Under Japanese law<ref>Act No. 147 of 1961 [http://law.e-gov.go.jp/htmldata/S36/S36HO147.html 原子力損害の賠償に関する法律], English [http://www.oecd-nea.org/law/legislation/japan-docs/Japan-Nuclear-Damage-Compensation-Act.pdf Act on Compensation for Nuclear Damage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110409065312/http://www.oecd-nea.org/law/legislation/japan-docs/Japan-Nuclear-Damage-Compensation-Act.pdf |date=2011-04-09 }}, Section 3</ref> the operator is liable for nuclear damage [[strict liability|regardless of culpability]] except in cases of exceptionally grave natural disasters and insurrection. Government spokesman Edano said this exception would be "impossible under current social circumstances".<ref>[http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/03/81077.html Natural disaster exemption not to apply to Tokyo Electric: Edano], 25. März 2011</ref>
Reactor operation is prohibited unless the operator concludes a private contract of liability insurance as well as an indemnity agreement with the government for damage not covered by private insurance. An amount of coverage of 120 billion yen per installation is required.<ref>Act No. 147 of 1961, Section 7</ref> The Japan Atomic Energy Insurance Pool does not cover damage caused by earthquakes and tsunamis.<ref>{{Cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-23/nuclear-cleanup-cost-goes-to-japan-s-taxpayers-may-spur-liability-shift.html| author=Natalie Obiko Pearson and Carolyn Bandel| title=Atomic Cleanup Cost Goes to Japan's Taxpayers, May Spur Liability Shift| publisher=Bloomberg| accessdate=23 March 2011| date=23 March 2011}}</ref> If damage exceeds the amount of coverage, the government may give the operator the aid required to compensate the damage, if authorized by the [[Japanese Diet]].<ref>Act No. 147 of 1961, Section 16</ref> On 13 April, the government considered a plan to limit TEPCO's liability to approximately 3.8 trillion yen (US$45 billion).<ref>[https://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFTFD00673420110413 TEPCO damages liability may be capped at $45 bln-Yomiuri]</ref>
==Economics== On 9 November 2011 the ministry of Finance reported that since the disaster in March 2011, due to rising energy costs, high oil-prices, and the need to replace the loss of nuclear power the current account surplus had fallen 21.4 percent to 20.4 billion dollars compared with the year 2010. A decline of seven months in-a-row. The trade balance had also fallen by 59 percent year-on-year to a surplus of about 4.8 billion dollars. The strong yen made the export of electronic components difficult. Through higher returns on overseas investments, however, the income account surplus rose 12.9 percent to nearly 18 billion dollars. Compared with 2010 the balance of international payments had shrunk 46.8 percent.<ref>NHK-world (9 November 2011) [http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/09_20.html Japan's current account surplus continue to shrink] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111104060131/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/09_20.html |date=2011-11-04 }}</ref>
Even though Japan saw a fall in manufacturing output for 2011, there was an increased use of fossil fuels for power generation, and this was the main driving force behind a rise in Japanese greenhouse gas emissions. Ministry of the Environment figures for 2011 show total greenhouse gas emissions of 1300 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent – 49 million tonnes more than in 2010 (a 3.9% increase).<ref>[http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/EE-Japan_sees_emissions_rise-1012127.html Japan sees emissions rise]. World-nuclear-news.org (2012-12-10). Retrieved on 2015-05-14.</ref>
==Technical developments== On 29 March 2012 a prototype of a new camera was presented by [[Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency]] (JAXA) and the [[Japan Atomic Energy Agency]] (JAEA) for the detection of gamma radiation. Images were made with a wide angle lens, the amount of contamination was presented in six different colors, the highest concentrations were red, after this yellow, green and purple. The camera was tested in February on different locations in Fukushima, the very accurate images of the contamination had already proven it effectiveness in the decontamination effort.<ref>The Mainichi Shimbun (29 March 2012)[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20120329p2a00m0na006000c.html JAXA develops camera that can 'see' radioactive contamination] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331172541/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20120329p2a00m0na006000c.html |date=2012-03-31 }}</ref>
==Compensation payments==
===The Nuclear Damage Liability Facilitation Fund=== On 21 October the president of TEPCO Toshio Nishizawa said that his company hoped to avoid capital injections from the [[Nuclear Damage Liability Facilitation Fund]], a foundation of the Japanese government. TEPCO would need financial aid from this fund to be able to pay the huge compensation payments due to the nuclear disaster at its Fukushima nuclear power plants. At a press-conference in Tokyo Nishizawa made the following remarks:
"We would like to properly conduct compensation by receiving financial assistance, while also taking rationalization measures to turn around management and keep on going as a private company, I think it's the best option for all to avoid capital injection as much as possible."
TEPCO might claim in October 2011 the sum of 120 billion yen of government compensation for the nuclear accident, this is the maximum amount set by a contract between the government and TEPCO. Compensation payments to people and companies that suffered damages through the crisis at that date already exceeded 150 billion yen. These compensation payments could rise up to 4.54 trillion yen (4,500,000,000,000 yen or around 59 billion US dollar) by March 2013, as was revealed by a report made by a commission of the Japanese government According to an estimate by a report compiled by a government panel, compensation payments could reach 4.54 trillion yen by March 2013. Special Government bonds, that carry no interest but could be cashed when necessary, would raise the money needed. The fund has also the right to make capital injections to TEPCO by subscribing shares. In close cooperation with this fund Tepco tried to seek financial backup for the future.<ref>The Mainichi Daily News (22 October 2011)[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111022p2g00m0dm012000c.html TEPCO to make efforts to avoid capital injection: Nishizawa] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111022184308/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111022p2g00m0dm012000c.html |date=2011-10-22 }}</ref>
At January 2013 TEPCO announced, that it needed more money to be able to pay compensations to the victims. At that moment the cost were estimated at Y3.24 trillion ($38 billion), up Y697 billion since March 2012, when the last calculation was made. In October 2011, seven months after the disaster the first assumption had been Y1.1 trillion. Since then, TEPCO already received Y1.5 billion financial aid, but the cost tripled. Besides the compensation costs, TEPCO would need some Y10 trillion to dismantle the reactors and clean up the radioactive polluted areas.<ref>The Tokyo Times (04 January 2013) [http://www.tokyotimes.com/2013/fukushima-operator-needs-more-money-to-compensate-victims/ Fukushima operator needs more money to compensate victims]</ref>
===Compensation criteria for former residents of the evacuation zones=== In February 2012 new restitution standards were set by the Japanese government center for settling disputes over compensation for nuclear accidents for the ongoing Fukushima nuclear crisis:
TEPCO was ordered to pay:
* to every person that was told to leave their home in accordance with official evacuation advisories. ** 100,000 yen per month ** after 7 months this amount should not be halved, as initially was planned. * to all people that evacuated on their own initiative: ** the costs of transportation ** the costs of accommodation expenses in excess of the amounts listed by the interim guidelines set by the government's Dispute Reconciliation Committee for Nuclear Damage *** 400,000 yen for children and expecting mothers *** 80,000 yen for all others.
TEPCO is also required to pay compensation for any damage caused by the nuclear disaster to properties in evacuation zones, even without on-site checks to confirm the properties' conditions.
The government of prefecture Fukushima was notified that in some areas the former residents would not be permitted to return, because there was no prospect that decontamination could be completed in any foreseeable future.
Settling the claims filed by evacuees about compensation, proved to be very difficult. Because TEPCO did refuse to respond to victims' claims, that their residences and other properties were worthless after the crisis. From 900 claims filed less than 10 claims were settled at the end of February 2012, despite all efforts of more than 150 lawyers, mediators and inspectors.<ref>The Mainichi Shimbun (25 February 2012)[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/perspectives/news/20120225p2a00m0na001000c.html TEPCO must be proactive in nuke crisis compensation negotiations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225172019/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/perspectives/news/20120225p2a00m0na001000c.html |date=2012-02-25 }}</ref>
===Compensation criteria for the tourist industry=== On 26 October 2011 TEPCO revised its criteria in calculating the damage suffered by tourist businesses after the crisis. Initial calculations by TEPCO included a deduction of 20 percent of the calculated losses. In the first announcement on 21 September 2011 TEPCO said that this 20 percent was thought to be caused not by radiation fears, but through the impact of the earthquake and the tsunami that followed. The new criteria offered two options: * 10 percent reduction, no limit to the period. * 20 percent reduction, but the period is shortened to 31 May 2011, between the first of June and 31 August the rate would be zero. The first criteria were based on data on the 1995 Great Hanshin earthquake that hit Kobe and surrounding area, this provoked much opposition.<ref>The Mainichi Daily News (27 October 2011 )[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111027p2g00m0dm006000c.html TEPCO revises compensation criteria for tourism businesses] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111030024504/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111027p2g00m0dm006000c.html |date=2011-10-30 }}</ref>
== Alternate energy sources == === Renewable energy === In September 2011, [[Tetsunari Iida]] launched the Japan Renewable Energy Foundation, which is backed by ¥1 billion (US$13 million) from Japan's richest man, [[Masayoshi Son]]. The foundation will bring together some 100 experts from around the world to analyse obstacles to [[Renewable energy commercialization|implementing renewable energy]], and offer policy recommendations to the new Japanese government.<ref name=renew>{{cite web |url=http://www.nature.com/news/2011/110830/full/477013a.html |title=Japan's new leader faces energy gap |author=David Cyranoski |date=Vol. 477, No. 13-14 (2011) |work=Nature }}</ref>
{{as of|2011|09}}, Japan plans to build a pilot [[Floating wind turbine|floating wind farm]], with six 2-megawatt turbines, off the [[Fukushima Prefecture|Fukushima coast]].<ref name=bb20110916>{{cite news|title=Japan Plans Floating Wind Power Plant |url=http://www.breakbulk.com/wind-renewables/japan-plans-floating-wind-power-plant |accessdate=12 October 2011 |newspaper=Breakbulk |date=16 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120521071742/http://www.breakbulk.com/wind-renewables/japan-plans-floating-wind-power-plant |archivedate=21 May 2012 |df= }}</ref> After the evaluation phase is complete in 2016, "Japan plans to build as many as 80 floating wind turbines off Fukushima by 2020."<ref name=bb20110916/>
=== Coal === The drop in energy capacity as a result of the partial shutdown of nuclear power plants has prompted the [[Shinzō Abe]]-led government to revisit the use of coal for energy generation, primarily through the increased adoption of high energy, low emissions (HELE) power plants that employ [[coal pollution mitigation]] techniques. By 2015, the share of coal in Japan's power sector had risen to 31% from 23% prior to the Fukushima disaster, but is projected by the government to fall to 26% by 2030 as Japan's energy mix stabilizes.<ref>{{cite news |title=Japan plans to build 45 new coal power plants in next decade: EIA |url=http://www.platts.com/latest-news/coal/sydney/japan-plans-to-build-45-new-coal-power-plants-27762428 |accessdate=23 February 2017 |newspaper=S&P Global Platts |date=3 February 2017 }}</ref>

{{Infobox Convention | name = Kunicon | image = | caption = | status = Inactive | location = Miami Beach, Florida (2004)
Saint Louis, Missouri (2005)
Atlanta, Georgia (2005)
Denver, Colorado (2005) | country = United States | first = 2004 | last = 2005 | attendance = }} '''Kunicon''' was a series of [[anime convention]]s organized by Subarashii Nation (formerly D20, Inc.) and held throughout the [[United States]] from December 2004 through June 2005. Originally named "Otakucon", the convention was renamed to "Kunicon" after controversy erupted over the name being similar to [[Otakon]], an anime convention held in [[Baltimore, Maryland]]. While Kunicon's original goal was to hold a convention in twelve major cities across the United States, these plans were cut short after 4 conventions as Kunicon continued to be plagued with controversy and cost overruns.{{cite web | first = Patrick | last = Delahanty| url = https://animecons.com/news/post/193/kunicon-cancelled-former-chairman-posts-attendance-numbers | title = Kunicon canceled; former chairman posts attendance numbers | date = 2005-11-02 | publisher = AnimeCons.com | accessdate = 2018-06-06}} ==Programming== Kunicon held several events over the course of a convention, including gaming competitions, [[cosplay]] contests, panels, live music concerts, anime screenings, and special performances.{{cite press release | url = https://animecons.com/press/post/96/otakucon-schedule-announced | title = Otakucon schedule announced | date = 2004-12-10 | accessdate = 2018-06-06}} ==History== Originally announced as "Otakucon", the convention started going by "OtakuCon Miami Beach" several months before the first convention in Miami, Florida. [[Otakon]] staff has reported that they had ordered a cease-and-desist,{{cite web | last = Koulikov | first = Mikhail | url = http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/feature/2005-01-26/9 | title = 2004 Year in Review: Anime Con Highlights | date = 2005-01-26 | publisher = Anime News Network | accessdate = 2007-02-28}} but the convention chairman, Manny Camacho, had been reported as saying that the name was simply changed to avoid confusion.{{cite web|last=Lillard |first=Kevin |url=http://www.fansview.com/2004/otakucon/121704a.htm |title=OtakuCon - Kunicon Plans - 2004 |publisher=A Fan's View |accessdate=2007-02-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061022003954/http://www.fansview.com/2004/otakucon/121704a.htm |archivedate=2006-10-22 |deadurl=yes |df= }} When the St. Louis event was announced as the second convention, it was announced under the name "Kunicon". Following the first convention in Miami, the staff cited an attendance of 5,000 people, which precisely matched their pre-con estimate. However, pictures taken by a fan photographer was used as evidence that numbers claimed by Kunicon were inflated. Kunicon continued to plan events for [[San Diego]], [[St. Louis]], [[Atlanta]], and [[Denver]]. However, San Diego was quickly canceled{{cite web | url = https://animecons.com/events/info/9223/kunicon-san-diego-2005 | title = Kunicon San Diego 2005 Information | publisher = AnimeCons.com | accessdate = 2018-06-06}} and the next convention was held in St. Louis in March 2005. The fourth and final Kunicon was held in Denver in June 2005, but went $30,000 over budget. The controversy came to an end when Emanuel "Manny" Camacho, the Kunicon chairman, announced on his [[LiveJournal]] that he was unable to contact Subarashii Nation and he could not see how the next convention, Kunicon Miami in December 2005, could take place. He also stated that the staff and employees of the convention have not been paid for their work. ===Event history=== {| class="wikitable" width="100%" |- ! Dates !! Location !! Atten. !! '''List of Fellows and Residents of the American Academy in Rome''' is a list of those who have been awarded the [[Rome Prize]] or were Residents of the American Academy in Rome. The Rome Prize is a prestigious [[United States|American]] award made annually by the [[American Academy in Rome]], through a nationwide competition, to 15 emerging artists (working in Architecture, Landscape Architecture, Design, Historic Preservation and Conservation, Literature, Musical Composition, or Visual Arts) and to 15 scholars (working in Ancient, Medieval, Renaissance and early Modern, or Modern Italian Studies).<ref>[http://www.sof-aarome.org/sof_directories.html Directory by Year] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080416233433/http://www.sof-aarome.org/sof_directories.html |date=2008-04-16 }}, Society of Fellows</ref> Residents are selected from scholars and creative artists at a further stages in their career for shorter residencies at the American Academy. Some of these Residents are marked (R) in the table below. Affiliated Fellows (AFAAR) and Visiting Artists and Scholars are not listed below.

page.title: List of Shakespeare in the Park productions at the Delacorte Theater

revision.text:
__NOTOC__ [[The Public Theater]] has produced over 100 plays and musicals at the [[Delacorte Theater]] in New York City's [[Central Park]] since the theater's opening in 1962. Currently the series is produced under the brand [[Free Shakespeare in the Park]], and all productions are staged at the Delacorte. In past decades, the series was branded the New York Shakespeare Festival and encompassed productions at both the Delacorte and the Public's downtown location near [[Astor Place]].
Officially ''[[Henry VIII (play)|Henry VIII]]'', staged in 1997, was celebrated as the final work of the [[Shakespeare's plays|Shakespearean canon]] to be performed as part of the series. However, {{as of|2017|lc=yes}}, the three parts of ''Henry VI'' have not been performed at the Delacorte except as the heavily adapted ''[[Wars of the Roses]]'' in 1970.
''[[Measure for Measure]]'' is the most-performed work, having been produced once during each of the six decades the Delacorte has been operating.

{{update|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox music festival |music_festival_name = Live Earth |image = [[Image:Live Earth Logo08.png|208px|The Live Earth logo representing the "[[Save Our Selves|S.O.S.]]" message.]] |location = [[Sydney Football Stadium|Sydney]], [[Coca Cola Dome|Johannesburg]], [[Giants Stadium|New Jersey]], [[Copacabana (Rio de Janeiro)|Rio de Janeiro]], [[Rothera Research Station|Antarctica]], [[Makuhari Messe|Tokyo]], [[Tō-ji|Kyoto]], [[Oriental Pearl Tower|Shanghai]], [[Wembley Stadium|London]], [[HSH Nordbank Arena|Hamburg]], [[National Mall|Washington, D.C.]] and [[Basilica of St. John Lateran|Rome]] |Participation = [[Madonna]], [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]], [[Metallica]], [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]], [[Bon Jovi]], [[Garth Brooks]], [[The Police]] |founders = [[Al Gore]], [[Kevin Wall]] |years_active= 2007 |dates = July 7, 2007 |genre = [[Pop music|Pop]]
[[Rock music|Rock]] |website = [http://www.liveearth.org/ www.liveearth.org] }} '''Live Earth''' is an event developed to increase [[Environmentalism|environmental awareness]] through entertainment. ==Background== Founded by Emmy-winning producer [[Kevin Wall]], in partnership with former U.S. Vice President [[Al Gore]], ''Live Earth'' was built upon the belief that entertainment has the power to transcend social and cultural barriers to move the world community to action. Live Earth seeks to leverage the power of entertainment through integrated events, media, and the live experience to ignite a global movement aimed at solving the most critical [[environmental issues]] of our time.[http://liveearth.org/en/liveearth/ About Live Earth] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100220005119/http://liveearth.org/en/liveearth |date=2010-02-20 }} accessed February 10, 2010 ==Live Earth 2007== {{main|Live Earth (2007 concert)}} The 1st series of [[benefit concert]]s were held on July 7, 2007. The concerts brought together more than 150 musical acts in eleven locations around the world and were broadcast to a mass global audience through television, radio, and live internet streams.[http://liveearth.org/en/liveearth/070707/ 07.07.07] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100216034100/http://liveearth.org/en/liveearth/070707 |date=2010-02-16 }} accessed Feb 10, 2010 ==Live Earth India 2008== The 2nd ''Live Earth'' concert was scheduled for December 7, 2008 at the ''[[Andheri Sports Complex]]'' on [[Veera Desai Road]] in [[Andheri]] West, [[Mumbai]], India and was managed by [[Kevin Wall]] who, after a request from former U. S. Vice President [[Al Gore]], planned to have the entire event take place in India.{{cite news | last = Jamkhandikar | first = Shilpa | coauthors = | title = Live Earth show to help light homes with solar energy | work = | pages = | agency = Associated Press | date = September 20, 2008 | url =http://in.reuters.com/article/entertainmentNews/idINIndia-35574720080920?sp=true | accessdate =2008-09-21 }}{{Cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Next Live Earth concert in Mumbai | pages = | work=[[Times of India]] | date = September 20, 2008 | url =http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Developmental_Issues/Next_Live_Earth_concert_in_Mumbai/articleshow/3504723.cms | accessdate =2008-09-21 }} In September, 2008 [[Reuters]] stated that, "the December event will see U.S. rocker [[Jon Bon Jovi]] and Bollywood's biggest superstar, [[Amitabh Bachchan]] share the stage, and is described by organisers as one of the biggest events held in India." [[Shekhar Kapur]], Nobel laureate [[Rajendra Pachauri]], [[Abhishek Bachchan]], and [[Aishwarya Rai]] also planned to star in the event. Additional acts included [[Shankar-Ehsaan-Loy]],{{cite web|title=Bachchans, Hrithik, Preity & 'Rock On' team at Live Earth India concert|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/news/2008/11/21/12214/index.html|publisher=Bollywood Hungama|accessdate=21 Nov 2008}} [[Hrithik Roshan]], [[Preity Zinta]],{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gREmh1eoIdTTV14Hz_RY_nWJ_vdg|title=Bollywood royalty lines up for Live Earth India concert], Agence France-Presse]|author=|date=|website=google.com|accessdate=22 September 2018}} [[Roger Waters]] of ''[[Pink Floyd]]'', [[will.i.am]], [[Hard Kaur]], and [[Anoushka Shankar]]. [[Palash Sen]] stated that his band, ''[[Euphoria (Indian band)|Euphoria]]'', was scheduled to launch a song written for the concert on the topic of [[global warming]].{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/who-wants-to-carol-inslowdown/00/21/342779/|title=Who wants to carol in a slowdown|author=Abhilasha Ojha|date=10 December 2008|work=business-standard.com}} ''Live Earth'' would have been broadcast by [[STAR TV (Asia)]], which works in conjunction with the ''[[STAR Plus]]'' channel (United Kingdom, Middle East) and the Star World Channel. [[MSN]] was "the exclusive global broadband partner for Live Earth India."{{Cite news|last=Bhushan |first=Nyay |coauthors= |title=Live Earth will have an encore in India |pages= |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=September 19, 2008 |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/world/news/e3if071151a9941bb2d0cd923bdde5d1684?imw=Y |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080921103827/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/world/news/e3if071151a9941bb2d0cd923bdde5d1684?imw=Y |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 21, 2008 |accessdate=2008-09-21 }} The concert was cancelled shortly after the [[November 2008 Mumbai attacks]] on November 26, 2008. Wall, Gore, and Pachauri stated in a joint press release that, "due to circumstances far beyond our control, we are saddened to announce that ''Live Earth India'' has been cancelled. We will continue to work for solutions to the climate crisis for the good of the people of India and around the world. But for now, our thoughts and our prayers are with the victims of this terrible attack, with the bereaved, with the people of Mumbai and with everyone in India."{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/Joint-Official-Statement-Live-Earth/story.aspx?guid=%7B64BE5B6B-AEDB-4A3A-994B-E0A017AE1EE2%7D|title=MarketWatch.com|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://music.ndtv.com/story.asp?id=ENTEN20080075159|title=NDTVMovies.com : Bollywood News, Reviews, Celebrity News, Hollywood news, Entertainment News, Videos & Photos|work=ndtv.com}} Some argued against the cancellation stating that "music could have helped fear-hardened Mumbai to ride the storm."{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/009200811300923.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203234405/http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/009200811300923.htm |archivedate=2008-12-03 |df= }} [[Jethro Tull (band)|Jethro Tull]] and [[Anoushka Shankar]], who also cancelled their 29 November Mumbai concert{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/Features/The_Sunday_ET/Backpage/The_flute_of_his_labours/articleshow/3718348.cms|title=The flute of his labours|work=The Economic Times}} after the [[November 2008 Mumbai attacks]], reorganized the performance as ''[[A Billion Hands Concert]]'', a [[benefit concert|benefit performance]] for victims of the attacks, and held it in Mumbai on December 5, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.abillionhands.com/abh_concert.html|title='A Billion Hands' Concert|work=abillionhands.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110312030135/http://www.abillionhands.com/abh_concert.html|archive-date=March 12, 2011|dead-url=yes}} ==Dow Live Earth Run for Water== The [[Dow Chemical Company|Dow]] Live Earth Run for Water took place April 18, 2010 and consisted of a series of 6 km run/walks (the average distance many women and children walk every day to secure water) taking place over the course of 24 hours in countries around the world, featuring concerts and water education activities aimed at igniting a tipping point to help solve the [[water crisis]]. [[Jessica Biel]], [[Alexandra Cousteau]], [[Pete Wentz]], [[Angélique Kidjo]] and Jenny Fletcher were due to lend their names and their time in support.{{cite web|url=http://www.wateronline.com/article.mvc/Dow-Launches-The-Dow-Live-Earth-Run-For-Water-0001|title=Dow Launches The Dow Live Earth Run For Water - The Largest Global Water Initiative In History To Help Solve The World Water Crisis|work=wateronline.com}} ===Controversy=== Before and after the event there was concern over the sponsorship of the Run For Water by [[Dow Chemical]], whose sponsorship of this event has been described as "the ultimate in [[greenwashing]]", given Dow's ownership of [[Union Carbide]], their refusal to clean up the [[Bhopal disaster|Bhopal site]], plus their direct responsibility for groundwater poisoning incidents in [[Morrisonville, Louisiana]]{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qFD1BB7hU9sC&pg=PA145 |title=History and Health Policy in the United States|work=google.com|isbn=9780813538389|last1=Stevens|first1=Rosemary|last2=Rosenberg|first2=Charles E.|last3=Burns|first3=Lawton R.|year=2006}} and the [[Tittabawassee River]] in Michigan.[http://jonbowermaster.com/blog/2009/11/dow-live-earth-the-ultimate-in-greenwashing/ Dow + “Live Earth” = the Ultimate in Greenwashing? (14 November 2009)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100410213720/http://jonbowermaster.com/blog/2009/11/dow-live-earth-the-ultimate-in-greenwashing/ |date=10 April 2010 }} accessed 11 Feb 2010 Their much-publicised water filtration plants in India have failed because the local population cannot afford to replace the expensive high-tech filters.[http://www.corpwatch.org/article.php?id=15485 Bhopal: Generations of Poison (2 Dec 2009)] accessed 11 Feb 2010{{cite web|url=http://www.bhopal.net/liveearth/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424035541/http://www.bhopal.net/liveearth/ |archivedate=2010-04-24 |df= }} ===Host cities=== The Dow Live Earth Run for Water was hosted by about 200 cities around the world, including: [[Amsterdam]], [[Atlanta]], [[Brussels]], [[Buenos Aires]], [[Cairo]], [[Cape Town]], [[Chicago]], [[Chongqing]], [[Copenhagen]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Istanbul]], [[Jakarta]], [[Jerusalem]], [[Jimbaran]], [[Karachi]], [[Lima]], [[Lisbon]], Los Angeles, [[Manila]], [[Melbourne]], [[Mexico City]], [[Minneapolis]], [[Monterrey]], [[Montreal]], [[New York City]], [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[São Paulo]], [[San Diego]], [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]], [[Santo Domingo]], [[Seattle]], [[Singapore|Singapore City]], [[Sydney]], [[Toronto]], [[Vancouver]] and Washington, D.C.[http://liveearth.org/run Live Earth - Run] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100417155226/http://liveearth.org/run |date=2010-04-17 }}, accessed April 15, 2010 ====Live performances==== Many of the cities featured live entertainment following the 6K run/walk. Artists include [[Melissa Etheridge]] in Los Angeles with [[The Roots]]; special guest [[John Legend]] in [[Brooklyn]]'s [[Prospect Park (Brooklyn)|Prospect Park]]; [[Rob Thomas (musician)|Rob Thomas]] in Atlanta; [[Collective Soul]] with special guest [[Sam Moore]] in Chicago; [[Kany García]] in Mexico City; [[Kevin Johansen]] and The Nada in Buenos Aires; and [[Slank]] in Bali.[http://liveearth.org/press/photos Live Earth - Photos] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100430192230/http://liveearth.org/press/photos |date=2010-04-30 }}, accessed April 15, 2010 ====Cancellations and protests==== Demonstrations against the run had been planned by the International Campaign for Justice in Bhopal.[http://www.hackneygazette.co.uk/content/hackney/gazette/news/story.aspx?brand=HKYGOnline&category=news&tBrand=northlondon24&tCategory=newshkyg&itemid=WeED13%20Apr%202010%2017%3A23%3A53%3A917 Hackney gazette news story] (accessed 20 April 2010) The Dow sponsorship of the Run For Water was protested by organizations representing the victims of the Bhopal tragedy, supported by [[Amnesty International]].[http://www.amnesty.ca/resource_centre/news/view.php?load=arcview&article=5283&c=Resource+Centre+News Amnesty International website: News: ''Dow cannot run from the legacy of Bhopal by sponsoring ‘Run For Water’ events'' 16 April 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917164256/http://amnesty.ca/resource_centre/news/view.php?load=arcview&article=5283&c=Resource+Centre+News |date=17 September 2010 }} (accessed 20 April 2010) Planned events were also cancelled in [[Milan]]. In [[New Delhi]], the event[http://www.joinliveearth.org/page/event/detail/friendsofliveearth/4jjdl Hindustan Sea Turtle Alliance-Aqua Justice Run] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100515233015/http://www.joinliveearth.org/page/event/detail/friendsofliveearth/4jjdl |date=2010-05-15 }} (accessed 3 May 2010) was protested by a group of activists[http://washasia.wordpress.com/2010/04/20/india-protests-against-dow-chemical-sponsorship-of-live-earth/ Washasia (news on water supply, sanitation and hygiene in Asia): ''India: protests against Dow Chemical sponsorship of Live Earth'' 20 April 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100430191152/http://washasia.wordpress.com/2010/04/20/india-protests-against-dow-chemical-sponsorship-of-live-earth/ |date=30 April 2010 }} (accessed 20 April 2010) who disguised their involvement by creating a fictitious front organization, the [[Hindustan Sea Turtle Alliance]], to register their event with Live Earth.[http://seaturtlealliance.org/events.html Hindustan Sea Turtle Alliance website: events] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100829073125/http://seaturtlealliance.org/events.html |date=2010-08-29 }} (accessed 20 April 2010) ===Beneficiaries=== All donations raised by the Dow Live Earth Run for Water will be disseminated to fund [[sustainable]] and scalable water programs. A growing global network of [[NGO]] partners including [[Global Water Challenge]], A Child's Right,{{cite web|url=http://www.achildsright.org/|title=Splash - The NGO formerly known as A Child's Right|work=splash.org/}} Akvo,{{cite web|url=http://www.akvo.org/|title=Akvo.org|author=Loic Sans}} Fondo Para La Paz,http://www.fondopaz.org/info/bolaugeng.html Indonesia Water Partnership, [http://www.lienaid.org/ Lien Aid], [[Pump Aid]], Wildlands Conservation Trust,[https://archive.is/20080809173718/http://www.wildlands.co.za/home.aspx ] and many others.{{cite web|url=http://liveearth.org/therunforwater/partners |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505081656/http://liveearth.org/therunforwater/partners |archivedate=2010-05-05 |df= }} ==See also== {{Portal|Sustainable Development|Global warming|Energy|Environment|Earth sciences|Ecology|Rock music}} *[[List of historic rock festivals]] *[[List of pop music festivals]] * [[Climate change]] * [[Earth Hour]] * [[Global warming]] * [[Hurricane Katrina]] * [[Individual and political action on climate change]] * [[Politics of global warming]] * [[Save Our Selves]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070718031728/http://www.liveearth.org/ Official Live Earth website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100312100912/http://video.liveearth.org/ Live Earth Video site] {{Live Earth concerts}} {{Al Gore}} {{Rock festivals}} [[Category:Live Earth| ]] [[Category:2007 in music]] [[Category:2008 in music]] [[Category:2010 in music]] [[Category:Benefit concerts]] [[Category:Musical advocacy groups]] [[Category:International environmental organizations]] [[Category:Music festivals established in 2010]] [[Category:Music festivals established in 2007]] [[Category:2007 in the environment]] [[Category:July 2007 events]]

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Lucas Papademos
{{small|Λουκάς Παπαδήμος}} | image = Lucas Papademos 2011-11-11.jpg | office = [[Prime Minister of Greece]] | president = [[Karolos Papoulias]] | deputy = [[Theodoros Pangalos (politician)|Theodoros Pangalos]] | term_start = 11 November 2011 | term_end = 16 May 2012 | predecessor = [[George Papandreou]] | successor = [[Panagiotis Pikrammenos]] | office1 = Vice President of the [[European Central Bank]] | president1 = [[Wim Duisenberg]]
[[Jean-Claude Trichet]] | term_start1 = 31 May 2002 | term_end1 = 31 May 2010 | predecessor1 = [[Christian Noyer]] | successor1 = [[Vítor Constâncio]] | office2 = Governor of the [[Bank of Greece]] | signature = Accession Treaty 2011 Lucas Papademos signature.svg | deputy2 = Panagiotis Thomopoulos | term_start2 = 26 October 1994 | term_end2 = 31 May 2002 | predecessor2 = Ioannis Boutos | successor2 = Nikolaos Garganas | birth_name = Lucas Demetrios Papademos | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|10|11|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Athens]], [[Kingdom of Greece|Greece]] | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Independent politician|Independent]] | spouse = Shanna Ingram | alma_mater = [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] }} '''Lucas Demetrios Papademos''' ({{lang-el|Λουκάς Παπαδήμος}}; born 11 October 1947) is a [[Greece|Greek]] [[economist]] who served as [[Prime Minister of Greece]] from November 2011 to May 2012, leading a [[provisional government]] in the wake of the [[Greek government debt crisis|Greek debt crisis]]. He previously served as [[European Central Bank|Vice President of the European Central Bank]] from 2002 to 2010 and Governor of the [[Bank of Greece]] from 1994 to 2002. He was a Visiting Professor of Public Policy at the [[Kennedy School of Government]] at [[Harvard University]] and is a Senior Fellow at the [[Center for Financial Studies]] at the [[Goethe University Frankfurt|University of Frankfurt]].[https://www.ifk-cfs.de/index.php?id=1717&L=0#papademos "Prof Lucas Papademos", Goethe University Frankfurt] Retrieved 12 November 2011. ==Early life and education== Papademos was born in [[Athens]] to parents who came from the town of [[Desfina]] in [[Phocis]].[http://www.tanea.gr/ellada/article/?aid=4670844 "Ta Nea" news-paper, online edition, 7 Nov. 2011], in Greek language. After graduating from [[Athens College]] in 1966, Papademos was accepted into the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], where he gained a bachelor's degree in physics in 1970, a master's degree in electrical engineering in 1972, and a doctorate in economics in 1978. ==Career as an economist== [[File:Ecofin Papadimos Sarris Alogoskoufis 2007 07 10.jpg|thumb|left|Lucas Papademos as Vice President of the European Central Bank, Michalis Sarris, Finance Minister of [[Cyprus]] and George Alogoskoufis, Finance Minister of Greece during a 2007 ECOFIN at Brussels.]] In 1975, he worked with [[Franco Modigliani]] on the [[NAIRU]] concept.{{cite journal |last=Modigliani |first=Franco |first2=Lucas |last2=Papademos |year=1975 |title=Targets for Monetary Policy in the Coming Year |journal=Brookings Papers on Economic Activity |volume=1975 |issue=1 |pages=141–165 |publisher=The Brookings Institution |jstor=2534063 }} He engaged in a career in [[academia]], teaching economics at [[Columbia University]] from 1975 until 1984, before moving to the [[University of Athens]] in 1988.{{cite web|url=http://www.hks.harvard.edu/about/faculty-staff-directory/lucas-papademos |title=Harvard Kennedy School |publisher=Harvard Kennedy School |date= |accessdate=6 November 2011}} His work as an economist began in 1980, when he was appointed Senior Economist at the [[Federal Reserve Bank of Boston]]. He joined the [[Bank of Greece]] in 1985 as its [[Chief Economist]], rising to the rank of Deputy Governor in 1993, and finally [[Governor]] in 1994. During his time as Governor of the central bank, Papademos was involved in Greece's transition from the drachma to the [[euro]] as its national currency. After leaving the Bank of Greece in 2002, Papademos became the Vice President to [[Wim Duisenberg]], and then [[Jean-Claude Trichet]], at the [[European Central Bank]] from 2002 to 2010. In 2010 he served as an economic advisor to [[Prime Minister of Greece|Greek Prime Minister]] [[George Papandreou]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financialcrisis/8867331/Lucas-Papademos-profile.html |title=Lucas Papademos: profile |publisher=The Telegraph |date=3 November 2011 |accessdate=7 November 2011 |location=London}} He was previously a member of the non-governmental group [[Trilateral Commission]].Trilateral Commission Website, [http://www.trilateral.org/download/file/EU_list_10-11.pdf European Group Members]Trilateral Commission Website, [http://www.trilateral.org/download/file/TC_list_12-11%282%29.pdf European Group Members-Update December 2011] He is a member of the [[Academy of Athens (modern)|Academy of Athens]]. He has published numerous articles in the fields of macroeconomic theory, the structure and functioning of financial markets, monetary analysis and policy, theory of chaos as well as on subjects concerning the economic performance, financial stability, financial instability and economic policy in the [[European Union]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eurofi.net/Speakers/index.php?idspeak=34 |title=Lucas Papademas |publisher=Eurofi (www.eurofi.net) |date= |accessdate=7 November 2011}} He has also delivered addresses on the [[Greek debt crisis]].{{cite web |url=http://csis.org/multimedia/video-european-economic-crisis-seminar-series-case-greece-keynote |title=Video: The European Economic Crisis Seminar Series: The Case of Greece – Keynote |publisher=Center for Strategic and International Studies |date=11 April 2011 |accessdate=7 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111108233714/http://csis.org/multimedia/video-european-economic-crisis-seminar-series-case-greece-keynote |archivedate=8 November 2011 |df= }} ==Prime Minister of Greece== [[File:Lucas Papademos - Plenary Hall, Parliament 16 November 2011 (6).jpg|thumb|left|Prime Minister Papademos speaking to the [[Hellenic Parliament]] on 14 November 2011]] {{see also|Greek government debt crisis|European sovereign debt crisis#Greece|Sixth austerity package (Greece)}} Papademos was first proposed as a potential caretaker [[Prime Minister of Greece]] in early November 2011, after Prime Minister [[George Papandreou]] offered to resign and allow a [[national unity government|provisional coalition government]] to deal with the major political turmoil caused by the country's [[Greek debt crisis|debt crisis]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-15671354 |title=Lucas Papademos named as new Greek prime minister |publisher=BBC |date= 10 November 2011|accessdate=10 November 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/10/lucas-papademos-greece-interim-coalition|title=Lucas Papademos to lead Greece's interim coalition government|date=10 November 2011|work=Guardian (UK)|accessdate=10 November 2011|location=London|first=Helena|last=Smith}} Lucas Papademos set two conditions upon which he would accept the offer of being Prime Minister of this provisional government. The first, was that the new government would not have a very restricted life span as [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]] had demanded, and the second was that political figures from both New Democracy and the [[Panhellenic Socialist Movement]] (PASOK) would participate in the government. Both of these were initially vetoed by New Democracy, but after several days of negotiations they relented and accepted Papademos' demands. This enabled Papademos to form a government made up of PASOK and New Democracy, with the support of the far-right [[Popular Orthodox Rally]]. After a week of political turmoil and negotiations between parties triggered by Papandreou's resignation, Papademos was sworn in as Prime Minister of Greece on 11 November 2011, unveiling his [[Coalition Cabinet of Lucas Papademos|provisional Cabinet]] shortly afterwards.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/11/us-greece-f-idUSTRE7AA2H720111111 |title=Papademos sworn in, heads Greek cabinet of stalwarts |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=11 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111111164259/https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/11/us-greece-f-idUSTRE7AA2H720111111 |archivedate=November 11, 2011 }} The other two parliamentary parties, the [[Communist Party of Greece|Communist Party]] and the [[Coalition of the Radical Left]] (SYRIZA), had refused Papandreou's invitation to participate in the government.{{cite web|title=Political opposition divided over unity government|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_07/11/2011_413717|publisher=e.kathemerini.com|accessdate=11 November 2011|date=7 November 2011}} The provisional government also marks the first time that the far-right has played a part in any Greek government since the fall of the [[Greek military junta of 1967–1974|military junta]] in 1974.{{cite news|title=Papademos sworn in to lead party-packed Greek cabinet|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/11/11/uk-greece-f-idUKTRE7AA2R420111111|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=12 November 2011|date=11 November 2011}} Papademos stated that his government's primary task would be to facilitate the [[Greek financial crisis|financial bailout]] from the European Union - which was provided on the condition that severe budget austerity be implemented - and to lead the country until elections could be held. Papademos also stated that his sole priority as Prime Minister would be to try to keep Greece within the [[Eurozone]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-15691697 |title=Greece swears in unity cabinet and PM Lucas Papademos |publisher=BBC |date= 11 November 2011|accessdate=11 November 2011}} In January 2012, Papademos warned that workers would have to accept substantial cuts in their income in order for a default to be avoided. He also told business and union leaders that the "troika" — the European Union, the [[International Monetary Fund]] and the ECB — was looking for Greece to take steps to open up so-called closed professions, as well as adjustments to the minimum wage, abolition of Christmas and summer vacation bonuses and automatic wage increases.{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-01-04/papademos-warns-fellow-greeks-economic-collapse-looms-without-sacrifice.html | work=Bloomberg | first1=Maria | last1=Petrakis | first2=Natalie | last2=Weeks | title=Papademos Warns Fellow Greeks Economic Collapse Looms Without Sacrifice | date=5 January 2012}} Papademos also declared in January that his provisional government would last until at least April, instead of February as was originally planned, so that further austerity measures could be implemented before an election.{{cite web|url=http://www.europeanvoice.com/article/2011/december/greek-elections-delayed-until-april/73071.aspx|title=Greek elections delayed until April|date=28 December 2011|publisher=|accessdate=25 May 2017}} In late April 2012, Papademos announced that he would ask [[President of Greece|President]] [[Karolos Papoulias]] to dissolve the [[Hellenic Parliament]], paving the way for [[Greek legislative election, May 2012|a general election]] to be held on 6 May 2012. Papademos had intended to stand down shortly after this election, but it resulted in a [[hung parliament]]. Subsequently New Democracy, PASOK, and the anti-austerity SYRIZA - which had jumped into second place - [[2012 Greek government formation|attempted to form a government]], but all were unsuccessful. Emergency negotiations to attempt to avoid a return to the polls took place on 13 May, but were inconclusive. On the same day, Papademos wrote to President Papoulias to inform him that the [[Ministry of Finance (Greece)|Ministry of Finance]] could only afford to pay salaries until the end of June, and that the need for Greece to recapitalise her liquid assets was "urgent".{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g3t4bsRXZd9h5nfOtmPEE6QaRoqQ?docId=CNG.ba931eaf00377ee5bd435da4bb4fc82f.671|title=Greek president calls for technocrat government|publisher=|accessdate=25 May 2017}} Negotiations in the aftermath of the election were unable to produce a government leading to a [[Greek legislative election, June 2012|snap general election]], which took place on 17 June 2012. In the wake of the announcement of the election Papademos stepped down, proposing [[Panagiotis Pikrammenos]] - a judge and the [[Council of State (Greece)|President of the Council of State]] - to replace him as caretaker Prime Minister until a permanent government could be formed.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-18082552 | work=BBC News | title=Greece to hold new election on 17 June | date=16 May 2012}} ==Personal life== As of 2011, Papademos has been married to Shanna Ingram for more than 30 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/vk/nl/2668/Buitenland/article/detail/3028354/2011/11/11/Vrouw-van-nieuwe-premier-Griekenland-is-Nederlandse.dhtml|title=Vrouw van nieuwe premier Griekenland is Nederlandse|date=11 November 2011|publisher=Volkskrant|language=Dutch|accessdate=18 November 2011}} They have no children.[http://www.grreporter.info/en/sana_ingram_%E2%80%93_dutch_artist_behind_success_lucas_papademos/5430 Sana Ingram – the Dutch artist behind the success of Lucas Papademos], 11 November 2011. Of Dutch descent, as of 2012 she was the President of the charity group Association of Friends of Children with Cancer.{{cite web|url=http://www.elpida.org/en/news/papadimou.html#.WFrDs32gvVI|title=Visit by Mrs. Shanna Ingram-Papademos to the Children's Oncology Unit|website=www.elpida.org|accessdate=25 May 2017}} ==Assassination attempt== In Athens on 25 May 2017, a suspected [[letter bomb]] exploded within his car, causing non-life-threatening arm, leg and stomach injuries to Papademos. His driver sustained leg injuries in the attack and another passenger, a banking official, was also injured.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/latest-news/617394/Athens-Terror-Bomb-Greece-Lucas-Papademos-Prime-Minister-Explosion-Terrorists-Security|title=Bomb explodes as ex-PM injured|publisher=Daily Star|date=25 May 2017|access-date=25 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-40052213|title=Blast in car injures Greek ex-PM|publisher=BBC|date=25 May 2017|access-date=25 May 2017}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Lucas Papademos}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040822083103/http://www.ecb.int/ecb/orga/decisions/html/cvpapademos.en.html Curriculum vitae] at the ECB website *[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-15643454 ''BBC Profile''] *[http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160516005209/http://topics.bloomberg.com/lucas-papademos/ ''Articles at Bloomberg''] {{s-start}} {{s-bus}} {{s-bef|before=[[Ioannis Boutos]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Governor of the [[Bank of Greece]]|years=1994–2002}} {{s-aft|after=[[Nikolaos Garganas]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Christian Noyer]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Vice President of the [[European Central Bank]]|years=2002–2010}} {{s-aft|after=[[Vítor Constâncio]]}} |- {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[George Papandreou]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Prime Minister of Greece]]

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Marc Short |image = Regional Media Day- 7-25-17 (36125962946) (cropped).png |office = White House Director of Legislative Affairs |president = [[Donald Trump]] |term_start = January 20, 2017 |term_end = July 20, 2018 |predecessor = Amy Rosenbaum |successor = [[Shahira Knight]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1970|3|3}} |birth_place = [[Virginia]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Kristen Short |children = 3 |education = [[Washington and Lee University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
[[University of Virginia]] {{small|([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]])}} }} '''Marc Short''' (born March 3, 1970) is a Senior Fellow at the [[Miller Center of Public Affairs]] and a contributor for [[CNN]]. He previously served as the [[White House Office#Office of Legislative Affairs|White House Director of Legislative Affairs]] for [[Donald Trump|President Trump]]; Chief of Staff for Senator [[Kay Bailey Hutchison]]; Chief of Staff for the [[Republican Conference of the United States House of Representatives|House Republican Conference]]; and President of [[Freedom Partners|Freedom Partners Chamber of Commerce]]. ==Early life and education== Short was born in [[Virginia]]. He graduated from [[Washington and Lee University]] in 1992.{{cite news|last1=Cheney|first1=Kyle|last2=Nussbaum|first2=Matthew|title=Donald Trump’s man on the Hill|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/who-is-marc-short-trump-legislative-liaison-233710|work=Politico|date=January 18, 2017}} ==Career== Short served as finance director for [[Oliver North]]'s unsuccessful [[United States Senate election in Virginia, 1994|1994 Senate campaign in Virginia]]. He then worked as spokesperson and executive director for The Freedom Alliance. Short was also the executive director of [[Young America's Foundation]]. In 1998, the group purchased the [[Reagan Ranch]] in California,{{cite news|last1=Lach|first1=Eric|title=Meet The Man Who Runs The Koch Brothers' Secret Bank|url=http://talkingpointsmemo.com/muckraker/meet-the-man-who-runs-the-koch-brothers-secret-bank|work=TPM|date=September 16, 2013|language=en}} with the intention of using it for leadership seminars for college students. Short managed the property with his wife and got his start in fundraising from conservative donors. The Shorts then returned to Virginia, where he received his MBA from the [[University of Virginia]]. Following his graduation, Short was hired as a spokesperson for the [[Department of Homeland Security]]. He then worked for Republican Senator [[Kay Bailey Hutchison]], eventually becoming her chief of staff. When Hutchison ran for Governor of Texas, Short started working for then-Congressman [[Mike Pence]], who named him chief of staff for the [[Republican Conference of the United States House of Representatives|House Republican Conference]] in 2009. He remained in the position until 2011. Short was then hired by [[Freedom Partners]], a non-profit, 501(c)(6) chamber of commerce located in Arlington, Virginia that is largely funded by [[Charles Koch|Charles]] and [[David Koch]]. He served as the organization's President from 2011 to 2016. In February 2016, Short left his position at Freedom Partners to start his own consulting firm. Among his clients were [[Marco Rubio]]'s presidential campaign and Pence's Indiana gubernatorial campaign. Pence eventually withdrew from the gubernatorial race to become Trump's running mate. On June 16, 2016, Short was named Communications Advisor to then Vice Presidential candidate Pence.{{cite news|last1=Goldmacher|first1=Shane|title=Trump expected to name Marc Short legislative affairs director|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/donald-trump-administration/2017/01/trump-legislative-affairs-director-233113|work=Politico|date=January 2, 2017}}{{cite news|title=The Latest: Trump campaign names staffers to help Pence|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2016-07-16/the-latest-northeastern-delegates-get-the-prime-rnc-seats|work=US News|agency=AP|date=July 16, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Rucker|first1=Philip|last2=Gold|first2=Matea|title=Mike Pence integrates longtime advisers with Trump campaign|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/07/16/mike-pence-integrates-longtime-advisers-with-trump-campaign/|work=Washington Post|date=July 16, 2016}} President Trump named Short the Director of Legislative Affairs on January 4, 2017.{{cite news|last1=Nakamura|first1=David|title=Trump announces additional White House staff|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2017/01/04/trump-announces-additional-white-house-staff/|work=Washington Post|date=January 4, 2017}} Short announced he would leave the White House post in the summer of 2018, citing “diminishing returns” of pushing President Donald Trump’s agenda.{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/white-house-capitol-hill-envoy-to-leave-post-citing-diminishing-returns-1529002465 |title=White House Capitol Hill Envoy to Leave Post, Citing ‘Diminishing Returns’ |author=Michael C. Bender |date=June 14, 2018 |website=[[WSJ.com]] |access-date=June 15, 2018}} ==Personal life== Marc and Kristen Short were married in 1997.{{cite news|last1=Purdum|first1=Todd S.|title=Keeping Reagan's Legacy Alive at His Old Ranch|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/24/us/keeping-reagan-s-legacy-alive-at-his-old-ranch.html|work=The New York Times|date=May 24, 1998}} They have three children and live in [[Arlington, Virginia]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ustream.tv/recorded/9308486 Short at the Reagan Ranch Roundtable], 2010. {{Trump Administration personnel}} {{Trump Executive Office}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Short, Marc}} [[Category:1970 births]] [[Category:Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016]] [[Category:People associated with the United States presidential election, 2016]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:United States congressional aides]] [[Category:United States presidential advisors]] [[Category:University of Virginia alumni]] [[Category:Virginia Republicans]] [[Category:Washington and Lee University alumni]]
